column17: Journalists, following the call of the SNJT, protested against attempts from the government and police to curtail freedom of speech.

column7: SNJT: National Union of Tunisian Journalists
column17: Journalists, following the call of the SNJT, protested against attempts from the government and police to curtail freedom of speech.
Youth burned tires and blocked roads in the town of Ain Draham in protest against security campaign targeting the sale of contraband fuel.
Security forces dispersed rioters by firing teargas in the area of Louata, between Bizerte and Menzel Bourguiba, the rioters responded by throwing stones.

column7: ISIE: Independent High Authority for Elections
column17: Electoral workers and officials resumed a sit-in and hunger strike at the ISIE headquarters in Berges du Lac area (Cite El Khadra district) of Tunis, the sit-in was staged in protest against the unsolved question of tenure and the dismissal of three co-workers.
The civil and political coalition Tunisians for Palestine protested outside the Bardo Palace against the delayed examination of the draft bill on the criminalisation of normalisation with the Israel.
A heavy explosion was heard at Jebel Chaambi, Kasserine, presumably an IED planted by militants of the Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade, military units moved out to contrl the site of the explosion.

Protesters gathered outside the headquarters of the state-run Gafsa Phosphate Company calling on the government to find a solution to the crisis within the country's phosphate industry as a result of blockades and protests.
Dozens of teachers protested outside the UGTT headquarters in downtown Tunis, calling for improved work conditions and benefits.

column16: Shems FM; Menastream; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; Jawhara
column17: A shepherd was wounded by the explosion of an IED in the area of Faj Hassine at Jebel Chaambi, Kasserine Governorate. The IED was most likely planted by militants of the Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade.

Family members and people close to a shepherd who was wounded by an IED at Jebel Chaambi blocked the main road near the General Hospital in Kasserine, the road was later opened after negotiations with authorities.

A Tunisian army patrol intercepted and opened fire on a vehicle in the area of Borj El Khadra in the extreme south on the border with Libya, the occupants of the vehicle were forced to stop and exchanged fire with the patrol before escaping back across the border into Libya, the military patrol seized the vehicle which contained ammunition boxes with a total of 1388 rounds, binoculars, and an artisanal grenade.

A ranger was found murdered in the area of Hammam-Sraya, north of Ghardimaou near the border with Algeria, the circumstances of the victims death is unknown, although the area has a documented presence of militants as well as recent activity.

column16: Tunisie Numerique; Kapitalis; Mosaique FM; Shems FM
column17: Two presumed militants of the Soldiers of the Caliphate entered the home of their uncle and tortured him including pulling his nails out in Sidi Ali Ben Aoun, the victim later succumbed to his wounds.

column16: Tunisie Numerique; Mosaique FM; Shems FM; Akher Khabar; Menastream
column17: A shepherd was wounded and had his leg amputated following the explosion of an IED/landmine in the area of Faj Hassine at Jebel Chaambi, Kasserine, the explosive device was most likely planted by militants of the Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade.
Fishermen in Thyna gathered at the water treatment plant to protest against pollution caused by chemicals and petrochemicals.

column7: OJTM: Tunisian Organisation of Young Doctors; Health Workers (Tunisia)
column16: Shems FM; Jeune Afrique; Mosaique FM
column17: The organisation of young Tunisian doctors organized a protest march from the Faculty of Medicine to the Ministry of Health, claiming an updated law that regulates their legal status and safeguards their rights.

Parents of autistic children at a private center in Ariana organized a protest gathering in front of the headquarters of National Security in Ariana, chanting slogans calling for the release of the educators arrested for mistreatment of the children.

Unemployed youth and residents burned tires, blocked the road and the railroad linking Sfax and Gabes in central Mahres in protest against the results of a recruitment contest. Police dispersed the protesters by firing teargas.

column16: Mosaique FM; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse
column17: Sit-inners in Kamour staged a protest in downtown Tataouine, demanding the government to implement various points agreed upon amidst negotiations last summer.
Policemen both in uniform and plain clothing gathered outside the court in Ben Arous, chanting slogans demanding the release of their colleagues, being detained on accusations of torture.
Teachers in Sidi Bouzid staged a protest claiming that the Ministry of Education has not responded to their demands.
Parents to autistic children in Gafsa stage a demonstration in protest against the ill-treatment of autistic children in Ariana.
Judges protested outside the courthouse in Ben Arous against the pressure attacks from policemen who demand the release of their colleagues.
Some forty people staged a protest at the headquarters of a bank demanding to get their money that was stolen from them by a bank employee.
Youth burned tires and blocked the road to Gafsa in protest against being unemployed.
Renewed protests in Tatouine against the non-implementation of the agreement signed between Kamour protesters and the government in June last summer.

On 3 March, it was reported that pharmaceutical workers for the forth day in a row protested against the violation of the union rights and intimidation of workers including delayed payments their annual grants.
On March 6, journalists gathered outside of the headquarters of Dar Assabah to protest the divestment of the media company confiscated by the government.
Security Measures: On March 6, President Beji Caid Essebsi extended the state of emergency by seven months counted from March 12

column7: SFDGUI: Union of Civil Servants of the General Directorate for Intervention Units
column17: On March 6, security officers from intervention units staged a protest in Sidi Bouzid demanding promotions.
On March 8, protesters gathered outside the national assembly demanding that deputies refuse the prolongation of the work of the Truth and Dignity Commission headed by Sihem Ben Sedrine.
On March 9, customs officers gathered in front of the offices of the surveillance and research brigade to protest against the arrests of several customs officials.
On March 10, Tunisian women marched from Bab Saadoun to Bardo to protest their demand of the same inheritance rights as men.
On March 10, Tunis Air employees staged a protest at the UGTT headquarters in Ariana, against the Open Sky agreement signed between the Tunisian government and the European Union.

column7: OJTM: Tunisian Organisation of Young Doctors; Health Workers (Tunisia); Students (Tunisia)
column17: On 12 March, protesters including young doctors and medicin students marched in Tunis to the Ministry of Health to protest against the non-fullfilment of their various demands.

On 12 March, employees at the national railroad company protested outside the company's local headquarters demanding the reopening of the line linking Gafsa, Tozeur and Sidi Bouzid, which has been closed for two years due to protests.

column7: UGTT: Tunisian General Labour Union; Teachers (Tunisia)
column17: On 15 March, substitute teachers who had protested at the local headquarters of education in Kairouan for several days, closed the headquarters of the institution and prevented the employees from entering and performing their work. The protesters had received a telegram from the Directorate of Education calling on them to show up at their workplaces within 48 hours or have their contracts terminated.

column7: UNSFST: National Union of Tunisian Security Forces
column17: On 15 March, unionists staged a protest at the National Security headquarters in Kasserine, the protest triggered intense debates with local security forces opposing the protest of the unionists.
On 15 March, a shepherd was wounded by the explosion of an IED in the heights of Touiref, the explosive device was most likely planted by Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade militants.
On 16 March, unemployed demonstrated on the main road in the town of Mdhilla, not satisfied with the decisions made by the regional council concerning the area the day before.
On 17 March, unemployed protesters clashed with police in the town of Mdhilla, the police dispersed the protesters by firing teargas.
On March 19, dozens of construction workers protested in downtown Tunis, demanding regularization of their work situation. A general strike was also observed in several regions.

column6: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column16: Xinhua; Ansamed; AP; Shems FM; Reuters; Menastream
column17: On March 19, combined units of the National Guard and the army pursued two presumed Jund al-Khilafah militants near the Sidi Toui National Park not far from the Libya border, amidst exchanges of gunfire one militant detonated himself without causing any casualties in the ranks of the government forces, the second individual was surrounded and later shot dead. An explosive belt, two grenades, a shotgun, a motorbike and other materiel belonging to the militants were seized after a cave in the area had been searched.

column16: Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; AFP; Shems FM
column17: On 21 March, angry protesters demanding employment clashed with security forces in the town of Mdhilla, the protesters also burned the police station, but were dispersed by the police who fired teargas. Security forces later withdrew and the army intervened to protect public institutions.
On 21 March, residents from Thala gathered to protest outside the National assembly demanding that the delegation of Thala would be transformed into a governorate.

On 22 March, protesters in Mdhilla forced workers at the Gafsa Phosphate Company and the Tunisian Chemical Group to evacuate their workplaces, hence blocking all activity at the facilities in the delegation.

column16: Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; Mosaique FM
column17: On March 27, army units clashed with Jund al-Khilafah militants on the slopes of Mount Salloum, forcing the militants to flee.
On March 28, youth in Souk Lahad attempted to set up blocks along the road linking Kebili and Tozeur, security forces fired teargas to disperse to rioters.

column6: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: On March 31, Special units of the National guard killed a Jund al-Khilafah militant around 22h in Douar Rogba near Jebel Salloum, Hassi Frid delegation, Kasserine, a Steyr AUG rifle, 5 magazines, ammunition and cash were also seized, other militants were reportedly wounded amidst the operation.
On March 31, protesters blocked the main road and burned tires in Tataouine.
On April 1, protesters blocked roads and burned tires in Tataouine.
On April 1, wounded of the revolution protested in Kasserine.
On April 2, employees at the state-owned electric company STEG protested outised the company's headquarters and that of the trade union in Bab Bhar.

column16: Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; Shems FM
column17: On April 2, a general strike was observed in Feriana and residents and members of civil society marched the streets in protest against unemployment.

On April 2, protesters clashed with security forces with one officer severely wounded after being hit by a brick in the head, the security forces also arrested the spokesperson of the Kamour protest movement.
Defusal: On April 2, it was announced that army units managed to detect and dismantle seven IEDs during the past week in the heights of Kasserine.

On April 4, families of victims during the revolution protested in front of the government palace in downtown Tunis, demanding that the names would be published in the official journal of the republic.

column16: Shems FM; Menastream; Mosaique FM; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse
column17: On April 6, army units clashed with presumed Katibat Uqba Bin Nafaa militants in the area of Zarzoura (Touiref), one IED (destroyed by controlled detonation), three bags, IED-manufacturing equipment, one AK magazine with blood traces, foodstuff and other objects were also seized or destroyed.
On April 8, unemployed youth in Feriana marched in protest towards the Bouchebka crossing on the border with Algeria.
On April 10, the Tunisian army clashed with Soldiers of the Caliphate militants near Jebel Mghila, Kasserine, one soldier was killed in the clashes.
On April 12, presumed militants of the Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade abducted four shepherds at Jebel Chaambi, Kasserine. The shepherds were later released after having their identities checked.

column16: Tunisie Numerique; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse
column17: Detonation: On April 13, a heavy explosion blew out an apartment in Kelibia, it is believed that owner of the apartment who has a background of Islamic extremism possibly attempted to manufacture explosives or IEDs. The blast caused material damages but no casualties.
On April 14, people gathered in front of the Municipal Theatre in downtown Tunis to protest against the airstrikes carried out by the western coalition in Syria.
On April 18, retirees in Kebili organized a protest march against the government's mismanagement of social funds.
On April 18, retirees in Sidi Bouzid organized a protest march for not having received their pensions increased.
On April 18, retirees in Beja organized a protest march to express their concern about statements made by some officials and rumors about reducing pensions.
On April 18, retirees throughout Tunisia protested against not having received their pensions increased.
On April 18, parents closed down a school in Enfida in protest against the cutoff of drinking water.

column7: IJABA: Union of University Teachers and Tunisian Researchers
column17: On April 19, some university professors from the union IJABA protested against the Minister of Higher Education Slim Khalbous while he was present at the Technopole in Sousse.
Looting: On April 23, presumed IISIS/Jund al-Khilafah militants threatened a shepherd and seized some of his sheep at Jebel Salloum.

On April 24, teachers staged a rally on the Mohamed Ali square in front of the UGTT headquarters in protest against any attempt to privatize the education sector. The students' parents confronted them to urge them to return to the classes, leading to heated discussions.
On April 25, retirees protested outside the UGTT headquarters, claiming their increased pensions and that the government respond to their demands.
On May 1, unknown individuals burned tires and sprayed insults on the walls of the Ennahda headquarters in Gafsa.
On May 1, traders at the Libyan market in Medenine launched a strike and protested in the city center.

column6: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: On May 2, Special units of the National Guard ambushed a group of Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade militants in the area of Ouled Boughanem at Jebel Ajered, one militant was killed in the ensuing clashes.

On May 4, rioters threw stones at security forces who were conducting a security campaign targeting street vendors in the Intilaka neighborhood, security forces responded by firing teargas to disperse the crowd.

On May 10, employees at the state-owned electricity company STEG protested outside the trade union (UGTT) headquarters in Bab el Bhar, this in conjunction with a one-day strike after talks with authorities broke down.

On May 14, residents in the Souaibia area of Jelma clashed with security forces who fired teargas to disperse the protesters, resulting in ten wounded in the ranks of the security forces and three among the protesters. Residents in the area refuse that the local well is going to be connected to the electrical network and the national water distribution company Sonede.
On May 15, people gathered in front of the U.S. embassy in Tunis to protest against the Israeli violence and killing of Palestinian protesters on the border with the Gaza Strip.
On May 15, protesters destroyed the well in Souaibia and confrontations with security forces resumed.

On May 15, an unknown individual attempted carry out a stabbing attack against a police patrol in front of the Great Synagogue on Avenue de la Liberte in central Tunis, the individual was overpowered and arrested. It is unclear if the attack was politically motivated although it comes amidst protests against violent Israeli suppression of protests along the border with the Gaza strip.

column16: Tunisie Numerique; Tunisie Telegraph; Mosaique FM
column17: On May 16, Tunisian air force carried out air raids while ground forces shelled Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade militant positions at Jebel Chaambi.
On May 19, unionists and civil society activists marched in support of the Palestinian cause and in condemnation against the U.S. decision to move its embassy to Jerusalem.
On May 20, protesters blocked roads and burned tires in Gafsa, disgruntled that the local football team had been relegated to the second division.

column16: Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; Mosaique FM; Tunisie Numerique
column17: On May 21, the Tunisian army ambushed a group of Jund al-Khilafah militants in the area of Oulad Moussa at the foothills of Jebel Salloum, one militant was killed and equipment seized.
On May 22, farmers from the area of Faid Methnane blocked the road between Sbiba and Sbeitla to express their grievances after having crops destroyed by hail.
On May 24, a dozen students protested in front of the headquarters of the Ministry of higher education in downtown Tunis, demanding their right to pass the exams.

column6: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) Border Guards
column17: On May 26, the Tunisian army shelled and the air force struck suspected Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade militant positions at Jebel Chaambi, Kasserine.

column6: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) Border Guards
column7: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard; Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019); Military Forces of Algeria (1999-) Border Guards
column16: Menastream; Ansamed; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse
column17: On May 30, Tunisian border guards thwarted an attack by presumed Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade militants against the border post they were manning between Haidra and the Algerian border, the guards opened fire causing the militants to flee, reinforcements from the National Guard, the Tunisian army and Algerian security forces coordinated a pursuit of the militants who fled towards the woods in Algeria.
On May 31, youths threw stones and molotov cocktails against security forces in a popular neighborhood in downtown Tunis, 13 were arrested.

On June 2, Islamic State (Soldiers of the Caliphate) militants detonated an IED on a pipeline transporting fuel and oil products from the Douleb field to Sfax, the explosion which took place in the Hrara area of Sbeitla and caused a fire. Media reports citing security sources initially dismissed the fire as caused by a presumed technical fault.
On June 3, members of Nidaa Tounes and independents staged a protest at the Martyrs Square in Kasserine in support of prime minister Youssef Chahed.

On June 5, dozens of residents organized a march in Hamma in support of the victims of the sinking boat off the coast of Kerkennah, the protesters also condemned what the deemed to be government inaction in the wake of the accident that left a large number of migrants dead.

On June 6, protesters including civil society activists and political figures gathered outside the ministry of interior in central Tunis and denounced the decision taken by prime minister Youssef Chaded to sack interior minister Lotfi Brahem which they deemed to be unfair.

On June 6, youth in Tataouine organized a nightly march to receive the corpses of victims of the sinking boat off the coast of Kerkennah, they also protested and blamed the government for the tragedy and demanded regional development and decreased unemployment.

column8: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column16: Mosaique FM; Tunisie Numerique; Shems FM
column17: On June 7, youth in Beni Khedache organized a protest against the tragedy of the boat that sunk off the coast of Kerkennah and left a large number of migrants dead. The protesters denounced the marginalization of the region, the socio-economic situation and the lack of prospect for development, and also attacked and burned the National Guard station and the delegation headquarters in the town.

On June 11, locals in Oueslatia protested and burned tires in reaction to being out water for ten days, the national electricity company STEG had cut the electricity for the company that distributes water to the town due to unpaid bills.

On June 13, locals in the town of Meknassi gathered outside the regional hospital to protest following the death of three month old baby, the residents also protested against the health security situation in general amid the deaths of several people following traffic accidents.
On June 21, people gathered between Ras Ajdir and Ben Guerdane in protest against what they deemed as mistreatment by border personnel, blocking roads.

column6: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: Weapons seizure: Units of the National Guard carried out raids targeting militants support network in the area of Mount Chaambi, a shotgun and ammunition was seized amidst the operation.
On June 21, residents in the town of Mdhilla prevented buses from transporting workers to the phosphate mines in protest against the disruption of drinking water distribution.

On June 23, Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade militants tortured and cut off the nose of a shepherd after stealing his animals in the area of Bir Bou Haya near Mount Chaambi, the shepherd later succumbed to his wounds, seven soldiers who were part of a convoy escorting the ambulance carrying the victim were wounded in a traffic accident.
On June 26, an independent candidate assaulted a female member of Nidaa Tounes, who was transferred to hospital.
On June 26, following the funeral of a murdered three-year-old girl residents in El Ala staged a protest.
On June 26, Kamour protesters set up a tent in downtown Tataouine and staged a protest as the beginning of a new series of protests.

On June 27, taxi drivers staged a protest in front of the governorate headquarters in Kairouan, claiming that authorities have not not fullfilled their promises for years and that the region lacks taxi cars.
On June 27, the family of a shepherd who succumbed to wounds sustained after having been assaulted and tortured by militants, protested between Feriana and Bouchebka, blocking the road.
On June 29, residents in Jelma blocked the national road in protest of the postponement to establish a regional hospital, burning tyres.
On June 30, the family of a murdered three-year-old blocked merchants from installing themselves at the weekly market in Dehibat, area of El Ala in protest.
On June 30, residents in Redeyef closed down laundromat at the phosphate company in protest against the disruption of tap water distribution.
On July 4, the family of a youth who was stabbed to death ransacked the regional hospital of Kasserine, and assaulted a health worker and a security guard.
Property destruction: On July 7, presumed Soldiers of the Caliphate militants burned the mausoleum of Sidi Hafiane in the delegation of Sbiba.
On July 7, imams and sheikhs protested in Tataouine against a report on individual liberties and equality, demanding the recommendations in the report not to be implemented.

column8: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) Border Guards
column17: On July 8, Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade militants carried out a complex ambush against a National Guard border guards convoy between Feija national park (Col du Chaid) and Sreia in the area of Ain Soltane. The attack was initiated by detonation of an IED followed by enfilading gunfire, six national guards were killed and three others wounded, the militants seized their weapons before withdrawing.

column16: Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; Mosaique FM; Shems FM
column17: Property destruction: On July 8, presumed Soldiers of the Caliphate militants burned the Sidi al-Hasnawi mausoleum in the area of Thamad (Tsmed) near Mount Mghila.
Looting: On July 9, alleged militants stripped a civilian of his mobile phone and emptied the tank of his motorbike between Blidet and Beni Mohamed, Kebili Governorate.

column7: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: Movement of forces: On July 9, combined units of the Tunisian army and the National guard launched a large combing operation supported by helicopters in the area of Ain Soltane in order to track down militants, this in conjunction with military movements by the Algerian army on the other side of the border.

column16: Shems FM; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse
column17: On July 12, an individual wounded two policemen (tourist security) by stabbing in Houmt Souk, Djerba, the assailant was subsequently arrested.
On July 13, security syndicalists gathered in Monastir to protest against the militant attack that killed six national guards in Ghardimaou.
On July 14, farmers in the area of Utica blocked the road in protest demanding compensation or more irrigation water for having been as they described it, encouraged to cultivate irrigated crops.
On July 14, parents of students who did not fulfil the requirements for secondary and higher education protested outside the Ministry of Education in downtown Tunis.
On July 16, residents from the areas of Hekama, Ayayta, Oued Beja and El Ksasba blocked the road and burned tires between Mahdia and El Jem in protest against water cuts.
On July 17, workers at a cookie factory in Oued Ellil staged a sit-in that lasted for almost two months, security forces broke it up on September 7.
On July 18, protesters prevented passage on the road for Libyan transport vehicles at the Ras Ajdir border crossing.
On July 20, residents of Saltaniya near Sfax (coded as Sfax at geoprecision 2) protested in the area against water cuts.
On July 20, residents of Essaadi in Sakiet Eddaier blocked the main road and burned tires, in protest against repetitive disturbances in the distribution of drinking water.
On July 24, retirees protested outside the UGTT headquarters in downtown Tunis against government plan to amend a pensions law.
On July 29, owners of illegal parasols and food outlets protested on the road leading from the beaches of Ghar el Melah and Sidi Ali el Mekki.
Looting: A group of presumed Soldiers of the Caliphate militants carried out a carjacking at Mount Salloum and after robbed a bank in downtown Kasserine.
On August 3, people protested in Tataouine against the COLIBE project which aims to enhance equality and individual freedoms.
On August 3, people protested in Ben Guerdane against the COLIBE project which aims to enhance equality and individual freedoms.
On August 3, a protest was organized by the Mahaba party in downtown Tunis against the COLIBE project which aims to enhance equality and individual freedoms.
On August 3, imams, preachers and local civil society activists protested in Sfax against the COLIBE project which aims to enhance equality and individual freedoms.

column7: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column16: Shems FM; Tunisie Numerique; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse
column17: Movement of forces: Around August 3, additional security and military forces were reportedly dispatched to the Kef Governorate on the border with Algeria due to the heightened security threat in the wake of a deadly ambush in the neighboring governorate of Jendouba.

column6: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: Weapons seizure: On August 3, the National Guard seized and artisanal grenade and an IED in a clothes shop in Sidi Ali Ben Aoun, the devices were most likely hidden by Soldiers of the Caliphate militants, two individuals were also arrested.
On August 4, imams, preachers and residents protested in Gafsa against the COLIBE project which aims to enhance equality and individual freedoms.
On August 5, people at the Ras Ajdir crossing protested to demand employment and development for the region, urging Libyans to cross into Libya through the Dehiba-Wasen crossing.
On August 11, traders continued their sit-in near the Ras Ajdir border crossing demanding employment and development for the region.
On August 11, several thousands of people protested in downtown Tunis against the COLIBE project which aims to enhance equality and individual freedoms.
On August 13, people demonstrated in support of the COLIBE report which projects enhanced individual rights and equality in downtown Tunis.
On August 20, army units shelled suspected militant positions in the western heights of Kasserine (coded as Jebel ech Chambi at geoprecision 2). It is unclear which group was targeted.
On August 20, army units shelled suspected militant positions in the western heights of Kasserine (coded as Jebel ech Chambi at geoprecision 2). It is unclear which group was targeted.
On August 20, army units shelled suspected militant positions in the western heights of Kasserine (coded as Jebel ech Chambi at geoprecision 2). It is unclear which group was targeted.
Looting: On August 22, presumed Soldiers of the Caliphate raided a house and seized supplies while threatening the residents in the area of Fej Et Tine near Mount Mghila.
Looting: On August 23, presumed Soldiers of the Caliphate militants raided a house near Mount Salloum in hunt for supplies.
On August 27, protesters burned tires and clashed with security forces in downtown Ben Guerdane, the security forces responded by firing tear gas.

column16: Mosaique FM; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse
column17: On August 28, protesters blocked roads and burned tires in downtown Ben Guerdane, the protesters also clashed with security forces and the police chief was struck in the head by a stone thrown, security forces arrested a group of protesters and dispersed the rest by firing tear gas.

On August 29, retirees at Avenue Habib Bourguiba in downtown Tunis, protested against poor living conditions, stagnation of purchase power and demanded that pensions would be increased in parallell with the salaries of active workers.
On August 29, a soldier was wounded by the explosion of an IED at Mount Mghila, Kasserine, the IED was presumably planted by Soldiers of the caliphate militants.
On August 30, five soldiers were wounded by the explosion of an IED at Mount Mghila, Kasserine, the IED was presumably planted by Soldiers of the caliphate militants.

On August 31, the Tunisian air force carried out airstrikes at Mount Mghila, Kasserine, and the Tunisian Ministry of defense released gun cam footage for the first time ever in connection to an ongoing military operation. A provisional toll indicates that at least four Soldiers of the caliphate militants were killed and three others wounded.
On September 3, candidates of recruitment contest for the Gafsa Phosphates Company (CPG) staged a protest in front of the company headquarters in Gafsa, demanding that the results be declared.
On September 3, residents protested on the road between Enfida and Kondar against the bad performance of public transport and the repeated delays.
On September 3, two soldiers wounded by the explosion of an IED at Mount Mghila, the IED was most likely planted by Soldiers of the Caliphate militants.
Defusal: On September 4, soldiers dismantled two IED planted by militants near Mount Chaambi.

On September 5, protesters blocked roads and burned tires in reaction to the self-immolation of a young man in front of the police station in Jendouba, security forces dispersed the protesters by firing tear gas.

On September 5, unemployed youth protested in Menzel Bouzaine against the non-implementation of an agreement signed to employ youth, preventing three trucks and train transporting phosphate to pass through.

column7: SNFSI: National Union of Internal Security Forces
column17: On September 6, SNFSI organized a sit in protest against aggressions of security personnel in front of the regional directorate of traffic police in Bizerte.
On September 7, police broke up a protest by workers of a cookie factory in Oued Ellil. The sit-in had lasted for almost two months.

column7: SNFSI: National Union of Internal Security Forces
column17: On September 6, SNFSI organized a sit in protest against aggressions of security personnel in front of the regional directorate of in Gabes.
On September 7, protesters in Menzel Gare blocked a train and burned tires in protest against increased tariffs for rural transport.

On September 11, residents from Thelja and Ennacim blocked the road between Metlaoui and Tozeur (coded as Metlaoui at geoprecision 2) in protest against against the disruption in the distribution of tap water.

On September 12, employees and journalists at Hannibal TV blocked a road and protested near the governorate headquarters, demanding the regional authorities to interevene in order to pay their salaries and regulate their working situation, there were confrontations with security forces who broke up the protest.
Non-violent activity: On September 15, about twenty Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade militants set up a fake checkpoint in the area of Bou Haya, stopping an Algerian national.
On September 16, residents in Ain Errahma blocked the road between Enfidha and Bouficha in protest against uncontrolled waste.
On September 17, residents in Tataouine staged a protest demanding regional development.
On September 17, parents of students shut down a school in Kasserine for not accepting their children.
On September 17, residents in Remada protested against unemployment and prevented cars and trucks from passing through the area toward oil facilities.

On September 19, fishermen, citizens and civil society representatives in Zarzis staged a rally in support of the Tunisian fishermen held in Italy for about twenty days after saving a group of illegal migrants.

column7: UGTT: Tunisian General Labour Union; Women (Tunisia)
column17: On September 20, the coordinator at the national office for working women, Hbiba Sellini accompanied by a number of trade unionists staged a protest in front of the UGTT headquarters in downtown Tunis since Sellini had been deprived of three months salaries while in the process of retiring.

On September 20, residents in Bourj Essalhi blocked the wind power plant in Sidi Daoud in protest against electricity cuts for certain residents due to unpaid bills, some refuse to pay because the wind turbines are installed on their property.
On September 22, residents in Ferjania (coded as Chebika at geoprecision 2) blocked the road and burned tires in protest against the bad road condition demanding it to be paved.
On September 23, people protested on roads in the Nabeul governorate preventing civil protection vehicles to enter, protesters demanded their respective localities to be prioritized.
On September 24, protesters and agents of the National Office of Sanitation (ONAS) clashed in Nabeul, security forces intervened and dispersed the protesters.
On September 24, two civilians were killed by the explosion of an IED in the area of Bou Haya at Mount Chaambi, the IED was most likely planted by militants of the Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade.
On September 24, people protested on the roads in Grombalia, between Grombalia and Sidi Aissa, and between Grombalia and Belli calling for better services in their areas.
On September 24, people protested on the road and burned tires in Sidi Amor in response to cuts in distribution of tap water and flooding.
On September 23, protesters demonstrated in the area of Bou Argoub, preventing civil protection units to pass, security forces dispersed the protesters with teargas.

On September 25, protesters blocked the road between Abida and Sidi Ali Ben Salem, burning tires, blocking school buses and shutting down schools in response to the deteriorated condition of the road in the area.

On September 27, youth in the Intilika area of Tunis clashed with security forces following the arrest of an alcohol vendor, the rioters threw stones while the security forces responded by firing tear gas, two individuals were also arrested.

On September 30, an altercation between a youth and a alcohol vendor led to street fighting between gangs in the Oued Ghenim area of Sousse, resulting in the death of one individual, groups of youth also attacked, ransacked and burned homes and shops.

column16: Mosaique FM; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; Kapitalis
column17: On October 1, two presumed Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade militants entered a home in the locality of Mejmaja near Mount Cheheb (coded as Kef Cheheb at geoprecision 2), Jendouba, seizing foodstuff and cash before escaping toward the mountains.

column16: Ifriqiya Muslimah; Tunisie Numerique; Ahabak ya Jaysh; Kapitalis; Al Andalus
column17: On October 3, Okba Ibn Nafaa Brigade militants detonated two IEDs against the army in the area of Abd el Adim at Mount Chaambi, the first IED struck an armored vehicle while a second targeted soldiers gathering around the destroyed vehicle, two soldiers were killed and ten others wounded.

On October 4, residents from Ghardaia in the area of Beni Khiar protested on the road between Beni Khiar and Beni Khalled (coded as Beni Khiar at geoprecision 2) against the bad road conditions due to flooding.
On October 4, parents to students in the primary school of Melitta protested on the road leading to the Djerba-Zarziz Airport against the lack of teachers.
On October 8, residents in Dzahibi (Dhahibiya) blocked to road leading to Enfidha and burned tires in protest, demanding the creation of a school and development projects.

On October 9, doctors, and nurses at the Ibn Jazzar Hospital, and members of civil society protested in front of the surgery and emergency departments at the Aghlabids Hospital in Kairouan, demanding an anesthesiologist and a resuscitator for the hospital.
On October 9, protesters in Metlaoui blocked a road and burned tires, they also threw stones at security forces, one protester burned a policeman by throwing burning flammable liquid.
On October 10, passengers staged a protest at the Kalaa Seghira train station in reaction to recurring delays and congestion.
On October 10, farmers in Bekalta protested on the road between Teboulba and Mahdia against the bad water quality.
On October 10, unknown individuals ransacked a mosque in Redeyef.

On October 12, protesters protested on the road between Beni Khiar and Beni Khalled (coded as Beni Khiar at geoprecision 2) in reaction to the deterioration of the infrastructure including the public light network and access to drinking water.
On October 12, jewelry traders observed a strike and staged a protest in downtown Tunis against harsh controls while demanding a revision of the law regulating the profession.
On October 16, people protested in the area of Ain Kmicha, demanding that authorities pave the road between Ain Kmicha and Magoura, the protest prevented access to the main road.
On October 19, a group of Islamist extremists assaulted a civilian in Bir Halima for drinking beer on the street, security forces arrested the perpetrators after having been alerted.

column6: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: On October 21, the National Guard shot dead a Soldiers of the Caliphate militant equipped with an explosive belt in the area of Tsmed, between Mount Mghila and Sbiba.
On October 21, two women were wounded by the explosion of an IED at Mount Salloum, one of the women had her leg amputated, the device was most likely planted by Soldiers of the Caliphate militants.

On October 22, journalists and employees at radio Shems FM staged a sit-in at the company headquarters in the Berges du Lac area of Tunis in reaction to unpaid salaries while also demanding the reactivation of the editorial board in order to safeguard the independency of the media company.

On October 24, protesters clashed with security forces throughout the day and evening in the Sidi Hassine area of Sijoumi following the killing of a smuggler by customs officers the day before, the security forces arrested 27 individuals although 19 were released and the area regained its calm the following day.

On October 24, football supporters of the team Esperance clashed with security forces at the Rades arena wounding 38 security personnel including 4 severely, 80 individuals were arrested with 12 kept in detention.
On October 24, journalists and employees at radio Shems FM staged a protest outside the government building in the Kasbah area of Tunis in reaction to unpaid salaries.
On October 25, notary bailiffs organized a protest in front of the first court in Sousse, demanding that the status of their profession be settled in line with other judicial professions.

On October 25, the president of the Free Constitution Party (PDL), Abir Moussi and a group of party associates protested in front of the headquarters of the TV channel Attessia in the Charguia area of Tunis, this in response to a verbal altercation that took place between Moussi and the host of a TV show who also threatened her on air.
On October 26, employees at the tax office in the Bab el Bhar area of Tunis, staged a sit-in due to a broken elevator that not have been fixed for four years.
On October 27, teachers at a school in Akouda protested in reaction to an assault by a parent against a teacher.

On October 27, protesters in the Sidi Hassine area of Sijoumi barricaded roads, burned tires, and clashed with security forces in response to the release of of customs agents who shot dead a youth in the locality.
On October 29, protesters in the area of Menzel Dar Belouar barricaded the road and burned tires between Sousse, Kairouan and Enfida.

column16: Tunisie Numerique; Mosaique FM; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; Shems FM
column17: On October 29, a shepherdess and her brother were wounded by the explosion of an IED in the area of Mount Mghila, the IED was most likely planted by Soldiers of the Caliphate militants.

column16: Le Temps (Tunisia); Agence Tunis Afrique Presse
column17: On October 29, a female suicide bomber attacked a police patrol by detonating an IED or grenade on Avenue Habib Bourguiba in central Tunis, wounding 15 policemen and 5 civilians. No group has claimed responsibility.

column6: Police Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) Prison Guards
column17: On October 31, two prison guards beat and injured a security guard at a hospital in Mahdia.
On November 1, families of martyrs of the revolution staged a rally at the presidency in Carthage, demanding that the president publishes the complete list of martyrs of the revolution.

On November 1, farmers in the area of Kondar barricaded the road between Enfida and Kairouan and burned tires in protest against deaths of sheep caused by the bluetongue disease and inaction by regional veterinary authorities.
On November 1, health workers protested against the assault by two prison guards against security guard at their workplace on a hospital in Mahdia.

On November 1, employees and officials of the Sfax municipality observed a sit-in in front of the municipality headquarters in protest against the behaviours and abuses attributed to certain National Guard officers.
On November 2, protesters in Mezzouna prevented trucks transporting phosphate to pass on the road between Mezzouna and El Guettar, security forces intervened and arrested four protesters.

On November 2, protesters in Kasserine observed a sit-in in front of the governorate headquarters in reaction to unpaid salaries by a contractor, security forces dispersed the crowd by firing teargas and alo arrested four individuals.

column16: Tunisia Online; Business News (Tunisia); Mosaique FM
column17: On November 2, members of Nidaa Tounes protested in front of the headquarters in the Berges du Lac area of Tunis against the fusion with the Free Patriotic Union (UPL) party, the protesters threatened to storm the headquarters and to use violence, security forces intervened by encircling the headquarters.

column16: Le Temps (Tunisia); Agence Tunis Afrique Presse
column17: On November 2, military forces carried out combined air and ground operations amid reports on the presence of a militant group in southern Kasserine.

On November 3, the Free Constitution Party (PDL) organized a protest in front of the Forum of Truth and Dignity headquarters in downtown Tunisia, the protesters expressed their discontent with the continued work of the commission and also chanted anti-Islamist slogans and against the commision president Sihem Ben Sedrine.

On November 5, residents in the area of Breika barricaded the road by burning tires between the locality and Ouled Bousmir (coded as Jabinyanah at geoprecision 2) in protest against their isolation due to the poor condition of the road.
On November 5, residents in the area of Sidi Amar barricaded the road with tires and stones demanding the paving of the agricultural road in the area.

On November 5, families of martyrs and wounded of the revolution protested in the Kasbah area of Tunis to condemn the non-publication by the government of an official list of martyrs and wounded of the revolution.

On November 6, the family of a victim killed in a traffic accident torched the transport bus of phosphate company which hit the vehicle of the victim in the area of Ben Bechir, between Sidi Ali Ben Aoun and Bir el Hafey.

On November 7, street vendors at the market of Sidi Bou Mendil in Tunis threw stones at security forces who were carrying out a raid at the market, wounding four security personnel, six individuals were also arrested.

column7: Teachers (Tunisia); UGTT: Tunisian General Labour Union
column17: On November 8, employees from the unions of higher education under the UGTT protested in front of the ministry of education in downtown Tunis ahead of the planned general strike.

On November 8, teachers staged a protest march in Beja against the low salaries of teachers demanding the implementation of a collective agreement which ensures teachers with higher minimum wages and social and health coverage.
On November 8, teachers staged a protest march in Sfax demanding the implementation of a collective agreement which ensures teachers with higher minimum wages and social and health coverage.
On November 9, health workers at the University Hospital in Medenine protested in response to an assault against a doctor by the relative of a patient.
On November 9, students at ISET in Tataouine protested, demanding the creation of a masters course.

On November 9, residents in Bir Ali Ben Amara closed down the public transport company in reaction to the poor services and the cancellation of buses between the locality and Bou Hajla, often making it difficult for students to return home.

column7: Labour Group (Tunisia); UGTT: Tunisian General Labour Union
column17: On November 10, workers gathered for a rally outside the UGTT headquarters in Tunis in preparation for a planned general strike.

column16: Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; Nessma; Tunisie Numerique
column17: On November 10, residents from Remada protested and prevented access to the road between Remada and the Dhehiba border crossing (coded as Remada at geoprecision 2), paralyzing traffic and movement across the border.

On November 11, a group of youth attacked a refugee by throwing stones at a refugee camp in the area of Beni Khedache after a mobile phone deal went wrong.

column16: Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; La Presse (Tunisia); Nessma
column17: On November 11, around hundred people protested in downtown Tunis against the appointment of Tunisian-Jewish Rene Trabelsi as minister of tourism.

On November 12, textile workers protested in Kef and prevented traffic access to a road.
On November 13, unknown individuals stab wounded a security officer off duty in the Halfaouine area of Tunis.
On November 13, textile workers protested in Kef and prevented traffic access to a road for the second day.

Around 14 November 2018, 4 unemployed women started a sit-in outside the governorate headquarters in Kairouan for more than 50 days to demand their right to work. The sit-in was brought to an end around 2 January 2019. [size=4]
On November 14, textile workers protested in Kef and prevented traffic access to a road for the third consecutive day.

On November 14, certificated civil servants employed at the ministries protested in front the of the government headquarters in the Kasbah area of Tunis, demanding the regulation of their working positions and salaries.

On 15 November 2019, in Tunis, the Tunisian President Kais Saied appointed Habib Jamli from Ennahda Party as new Prime Minister to form a new government .

column7: Police Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) Prison Guards

On November 17, residents in Metlaoui burned tires and barricaded roads in protest of the results of the environmental company recruitment campaign, a protester climbed an electric pole threatening to suicide, the protesters also closed down the offices of the municipality headquarters and the Gafsa phosphate company, protests continued overnight to Sunday.

On November 17, residents in Oum Larais burned tires and barricaded roads in protest of the results of the environmental company recruitment campaign, administrative buildings and schools were also closed down, protests continued overnight to Sunday.

On November 17, members of civil society organized a protest in Sousse, demanding the preservation of an old building dating from the colonial period.

On November 19, residents protested in Redeyef against the results of environmental company recruitment campaign.
On November 19, employees at the Teboulba municipality protested, demanding certain benefits such as working uniforms and school grants.

On November 19, residents protested in Metlaoui against the results of environmental company recruitment campaign, a protester threatened to suicide by climbing an electrical pole.

On November 19, residents protested in Oum Larais against the results of environmental company recruitment campaign.
On November 19, residents protested in Mdhilla against the results of environmental company recruitment campaign.
On November 19, parents of students in the area of Jehina (coded as Jehina Nord at geoprecision 2) closed down the school in protest against the absence of teachers.
On November 19, residents in Jelma protested in front of the municipality headquarters, demanding measures taken to prevent the spread of epidemics by insects such as the Nile virus.

On November 21, unemployed who had participated in a recruitment campaign for the Gafsa environmental company protested by closing down administrative buildings and schools in Redeyef.
