On December 3, representative of development councils in the agricultural sector staged a protest in front of the governorate headquarters threatening with resignation due to increased electricity prices.
On December 3, students in Hammamet threw stones at teachers in Bir Bou Rekba in protest against teachers boycott of exams, forcing schools to close.
On December 3, locals in the area of Naouara in Sidi Salem protested and prevented traffic access to the road in reaction to farmers plowing pastureland where their livestock graze.
On December 3, students protested and threw stones at teachers in Tabarka for boycotting exams.
On December 3, students protested and threw stones at teachers in Fernana for boycotting exams.
On December 3, students in Hammamet threw stones at teachers in Hammamet in protest against teachers boycott of exams, forcing schools to close.

On December 3, residents in the area of Nasrallah protested against the death of a student in a traffic accident preventing traffic access to the main road to draw attention against speeding and also demanding access to tap water.
On December 3, teachers protested at the Jalel school in Jendouba.
On December 3, youths in Menzel Bouzaiane burned tires and threw molotov cocktails at a police station forcing security forces to flee.
On December 3, some students and youths burned tires and carried out other acts of vandalism in protest against teachers exams boycott in Bouhajla.
On December 3, students burned tires and threw stones in the area of Bou Argoub in protest against teachers boycotting exams.
On December 3, students in Kairouan protested against teachers boycotting exams.

On December 3, residents in the area of Nasrallah protested for the second day against the death of a student in a traffic accident preventing traffic access to the main road to draw attention against speeding and also demanding access to tap water.
On December 4, attorneys and clerks at the court in Gafsa staged a sit-in in response to the issuance of a custody decision against one of their colleagues.
On December 4, the Tunisian ministry of defense initiated the process of transforming the Remada airstrip to a combined military and civilian air base.
On December 4, youths protesting against the arrests burned tires and threw stones at security forces who responded by firing teargas in Menzel Bouzaiane.

column7: UGTT: Tunisian General Labour Union; Labour Group (Tunisia)
column17: On December 4, a group of trade unionists staged a protest march in the Kasba area of Tunis to commemorate the 66th anniversary of the assassination of trade unionist Farhat Hached.
On December 4, students protesting against teachers boycott of exams in Kairouan threw stones against a bus causing damages.

On or around 2 December 2018, the recruits at the phosphate mine in Al Miknasi held a sit-in for more than one month outside the municipality to demand the start of their work for which they had been recruited and signed contracts.
On December 5, secondary school teachers continued their boycott of exams due to absence of response to their demands from the ministry of education.
On December 5, teachers in Gafsa staged a protest in reaction to comments made by the minister of education regarding teachers boycotting exams.
On December 5, teachers in Gabes staged a protest march and expressed that they will continue to boycott exams until new negotiations are opened.
On December 5, a group of civil servants staged a protest in front of the delegation headquarters in Hajeb el Aioun demanding answers to their social demands.
On December 5, security forces discovered an explosives cache in Sidi Bouzid and arrested eight individuals reportedly linked to the Katibat Al-Jihad wal Tawhid.
On December 5, civil servants in Regueb staged a protest and chanted slogans in front of the delegation headquarters.
On December 5, taxi drivers in Tozeur staged a protest and prevented traffic access to the main road in response to what they deemed to be abusive practices against unionists in the sector.
On December 6, employees at a hotel in the Borj Cedria area of Ben Arous staged a protest for not having received their salaries for two months.
On December 6, lawyers in Siliana staged a protest march, demanding the establishment of an appeal court in the area.
On December 6, people in Tataouine staged a protest, demanding the Kamour-agreement to be implemented.
On December 6, students in Chebika burned tires in protest against teachers boycotting exams, one student had its face burned.
On December 6, unemployed people staged a protest in front of the governorate headquarters in Kasserine, demandings jobs.

On December 6, residents in the Soltaniya area of Foussana barricaded the road in protest against the failure of authorities to provide assistance during the floodings as well as tap water, they further demanded jobs.
On December 6, students protesting in Kairouan threw stones against a teacher.
On December 6, teachers and parents of students in the area of Fernana protested against the assault of a teacher the before for confronting road users speeding on a road where students cross.

On December 7, it was reported that a homosexual man had been subjected to an murder attempt after being severely beaten and stabbed, the aggressors were arrested but subsequently released after a court hearing.
On December 7, teachers begun observing a sit-in the regional directorate of education in Sousse.
On December 7, civil society activists protested in front of the court in Kairouan demanding that the court sanctions a teacher accused of sexual harassment.
On December 7, protesting teachers stormed two educational headquarters in Tunis and staged sit-ins at the sites.
On December 7, residents and members of civil society protested in El Hamma against the plan to establish a chemical waste dump in Menzel Habib.
On December 7, teachers in Medenine protested against the decision to cut their wages due to their boycott of exams.
On December 7, teachers in Jendouba protested against the decision to cut their wages due to their boycott of exams.
On December 7, teachers in Sidi Bouzid staged a protest march in response to the decision to cut their wages due to their boycott of exams.
On December 7, teachers boycotting exams staged a protest in Kasserine.
On December 7, teachers boycotting exams staged a protest in Sfax.
On December 7, teachers boycotting exams staged a protest in Gafsa.
On December 7, teachers boycotting exams staged a protest in Mahdia.
On December 7, a group of civil servants staged a protest in Tozeur demanding their professional status to be settled.
On December 8, taxi drivers in Gafsa protested in front of the governorate headquarters due to lack of space for taxi cars causing congestion.
On December 8, civil society activists organized an anti-Israel and support for Palestine protest in Tunis on the anniversary of the Intifada.
On December 10, teachers staged a protest march in Sidi Bouzid.
On December 10, teachers in Ghomrassen staged a protest in front of the municipal headquarters against the decision by the minister of education to cut their salaries for boycotting exams.
On December 10, teachers in Jendouba continued to observe a sit-in at the regional directorate of eduction.
On December 10, lawyers in Kasserine protested against the finance bill which proposes the lifitng of the professional secrecy of the profession.
On December 10, residents in Menzel el Habib protested and observed a general strike in response to the plan to dispose phosphogypsum in their area.
On December 10, residents in El Hamma protested and observed a general strike in response to the plan to dispose phosphogypsum in their area.
On December 10, civil servants in Kebili staged a protest march demanding the settlement of their professional status.
On December 11, youth barricaded the railway track in Menzel Bouzaiane to protest the lack of development and employment.
On December 11, factory workers in Bir Lahmar burned tires in protest against non-response to their demands including the settlement of their working positions and social coverage.
On December 11, residents in Bou Selim staged a protest demanding improved social conditions.
On December 12, traders in Ben Gardane burned tires at the main square and prevented Libyan cars from passing through.
On December 12, students in Siliana observed a strike in order to protest and express their dissatisfaction.
On December 12, teachers staged a protest in downtown Tunis demanding reforms of the education and also called on parents of students to join their movement.

12-25 December 2018 (approximately), a number of unemployed people entered an open sit-in inside the headquarter of the municipality of Mellouleche in Mahdia for over two weeks to demand development and employment.
On December 12, youths in Kasserine barricaded roads and burned tires.
On December 12, teachers and lawyers joined forces and staged an anti-government protest march in Medenine.

column7: SNJT: National Union of Tunisian Journalists; Journalists (Tunisia)
column17: On December 12, the Sfax-Sidi Bouzid branch of SNJT staged a protest in front the headquarters of the court of first instance in Sfax in solidarity with two journalists who were assaulted while covering teachers-students protests in the city.
On December 12, students in Kairouan staged a protest march which escalated with stown-throwing resulting in a number of wounded students forcing security forces and civil protection to intervene.
On 13 December 2018, court clerks at the Bizerte Court of First Instance staged a protest against the suspension of one of their colleagues in Gafsa.
On December 13, traders in Ben Gardane burned tires at the main square and prevented Libyan cars from accessing the town.
On December 13, students protested in Ben Gardane against teachers boycotting exams, the students threw rocks wounding a teacher.

On December 13, driving school owners prevented access to the main road in front of the governorate headquarters in Sidi Bouzid in protest against the decision to establish a second driving test examination center.
On December 13, a group of farmers staged a protest in front of the governorate headquarters, demanding adjustment of the milk price with regard to production costs.
On December 13, youth in Thala threw stones at security forces after having gathered in front of a police station, the police arrested a number of them and brought the situation under control.

On December 13, lawyers forced the security barriers to the courtyard of the government building in the Kasbah area of Tunis and clashed with security forces, in protest against the lifting of the professional secrecy.

On December 14, Soldiers of the Caliphate militants assassinated a civilian in the area of Douar Khraifiya (Henchir Tsmed), the victim was the brother of a soldier murdered by the group two years earlier.
On December 14, teachers protested in Kairouan and affirmed that they will continue protesting and boycotting exams despite salary cuts until their demands are met.

On December 14, members and supporters of the PDL party staged a proters in front of the headquarters of the Pension and Social Welfare Fund of Lawyers in Tunis, receting the work of Truth and Dignity Commission and compensation to human rights victims of the former regimes.
On December 14, Soldiers of the Caliphate militants hijacked a vehicle at Mount Mghila and robbed a bank in Sbiba, seizing a significant amount of cash in Tunisian and foreign currency.

On December 15, citizens and civil society activists staged a protest in downtown Tunis to express their rejection of compensations to human rights victims of the former regimes with the argument that priority should be given to education, health, and security, the also called for the disclosure of the case regarding the secret device of the Ennahda party.
On December 15, residents in Djemmal stages a protest dressed in yellow vests, calling on citizens to defend their rights and dignity.

On 15 December 2018, a number of workers at the brick factory in Kalaa Seghira protested against the initial decision by the Municipal Council to close the factory, closing the road between Kalaa Seghira and Sousse.
On December 15, the coordination of Angry Parents staged a protest in downtown Tunis demanding that teachers respect the rights of children in light of teachers boycotting exams.

On 16 December 2018, a group of young people closed the border crossing in Bou Chebka and threw stones at the security centers there calling for the release of the young men arrested by the Algerian border police.
On 17 December 2018, a number of lawyers held a protest in front of the the district court in Makater to demand the construction of a new seat for the district court.

On 17 December 2018, a number of unemployed youths as well as some activists of the local office of the Association of the Unemployed (APT) staged an open sit-in at the municipality of Douar Hecher in Manouba to protest the deterioration of their social and economic conditions.
On 17 December 2018, teachers staged an open sit-in at the Directorate of Education in Bizerte to push the government to listen to their demands.

On 17 December 2018, court clerks at the Jendouba Court of First Instance and the rest of the courts of the district held a protest in support of their suspended colleague in Qafsa on charges of defamation.
Reported on 17 December 2018, protests in Metlaoui continued. Protesters blocked the main road between Gafsa and Tozeur demanding employment and development.
On 17 December 2018, the staff of the local hospital in Nafza staged a protest against the lack of resources affecting the medical services and the working conditions of the hospital.

On 17 December 2018, a night protest was held in Regueb. Protesters burned tires and demanded the implementation of the decisions of the Ministerial Council adopted on 15 December and the unblocking of some projects in the city including the driving test center.
On 17 December 2018, a group of unemployed graduates staged a protest in Sidi Bouzid against unemployment.

On 17 Dec, Tunisian demonstrators threw stones at the Algeria-Tunisia border post in Bouchabka, protesting the arrest of two Tunisian citizens by Algerian authorities the day before as they allegedly tried to enter illegally. The demonstrators, mostly friends and relatives of the arrested, caused extensive damage to the border post. One Algerian police officer was lightly wounded.
On 18 December 2018, a number of former workers of the brick factory in Bir Lahmar carried out a protest and set tires on fire in front of the entrance of the factory to demand its reopening.

column7: URAP: Regional Union of Agriculture and Fisheries; Labour Group (Tunisia)
column17: On 18 December 2018, the Regional Union of Agriculture and Fisheries in Gafsa organized a protest in front of the governorate headquarter against the deterioration of the agricultural sector in the area. The protesters demanded a review of the laws governing dairy and olive oil production.

Around 17 December 2018, for the second week in a row, civil servants held a sit-in in Hajeb el Aioun to demand the implementation of the agreement between them and the authorities and the resolution of their demands (first protest reported on 5 December).

On 19 December 2018, a number of residents of the city of Metlaoui and representatives of civil society held a protest in front of the headquarter of the National Security to demand the release of Hachem Hmidi, former minister of energy and mines.

column7: URAP: Regional Union of Agriculture and Fisheries; Labour Group (Tunisia)
column17: On 19 December 2018, a number of farmers held a protest outside the headquarter of the Regional Union of Agriculture and Fisheries in Jendouba and then they marched in the street of Habib Bourguiba toward the headquarter of the governorate.They called on the government to find solutions to better their situation.

column6: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column16: Crisis Watch; Tunisie Numerique; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse
column17: On 19 December 2018, the leader of Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM)'s local splinter group Okba Ibn Nafaa brigade was shot dead by the Tunisian National Guard on Mount Ouergha during a preventive operation.

column16: Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; Tunisie Numerique
column17: Reported on 19 December 2018, the security forces of Tunisia located and arrested eight members of the ""Katibat Al-Jihad wal Tawhid"" in Sidi Bouzid who were preparing to carry out attacks against security patrols and police stations in the region. At the time of their arrest, several weapons and explosives were also seized.

On 19 December 2018, a number of former employees of the Phosphate Company (CPG) in Mdhilla blocked the road and prevented the buses transporting the company workers to enter the compound. Their demand was to get their job back.

On 19 December 2018, thousands of secondary school teachers staged a protest in Tunis to demand a wage increase and improvement in their working conditions. A number of journalists were attacked by demonstrators which led the SNJT to urge its members to boycott the coverage of teachers' protests.
On 20 December 2018, lawyers staged a protest in front of the Court of First Instance of Bizerte against the Finance Act of 2019. They held a sit-in, which was said to be continuing as of Dec 26th.
Around 20 December 2018, environmental workers held a two-day sit-in in El Guettar to defend their rights and voice their demands.
On 20 December 2018, the lawyers in Gafsa held a protest in front of the Court of First Instance against the Finance Act of 2019.

On 20 December 2018, court clerks in Nabeul organized a protest in front of the Court of First Instance to demand the improvement of their working conditions and expressed their rejection of the intention of some lawyers to recruit outsiders without the required qualifications.

Reported on 20 December 2018, civil servants organized a protest in the sidelines of the National Forum in Gabes in which the Minister of Agriculture was present to demand an improvement in their situation.
On 20 December 2018, lawyers in Kasserine held a protest in front of the Court of First Instance against the breach of professional secrecy in the Finance Act of 2019.
On 21 December 2018, lawyers entered a sit-in at the regional branch of lawyers in the Court of First Instance in Sfax to demand the dismissal of Chapter 34 of the Finance Act.

On 21 December 2018, some individuals in a car fired on a security patrol stationed in the area of Slimane Kehia in Manouba. Later the minister of interior declared the shots were not directed toward security officers while some other government sources denied that shooting took place at all.

Reported on 21 December 2018, the police in Sidi Bouzid arrested 13 people because of riots during the night protests in several neighborhoods of the city. The rioters had deliberately blocked public roads in the last few days, set tires on fire, and threw stones at security vehicles.

On 22 December 2018, youths in Oulad Chalabi neighborhood of Sidi Bouzid staged a night protest in which they set tires and waste containers on fire and threw stones at security vehicles. Security agents used tear gas to disperse them.
On or around 23 December 2018, the residents of Beni Darraj in Zaghouan closed the road to Hammamet to claim their right to development and employment.

column16: Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; Al Chourouk
column17: On 23 December 2018, protesters threw stones and burned tires near the police station in Jabinyanah. The police used tear gas to disperse the protesters. The protest was staged after the death of a young man in an accident in a chase with the police.

column9: AIT: Association of Ivorians in Tunisia
column17: On 23 December 2018, Falikou Koulibaly, the president of the Association of Ivorians in Tunisia, died in the hospital after being attacked and stabbed during a robbery in Dar Fadhal in Soukra.

On 24 December 2018, hundreds of Ivorian nationals organized a protest in Tunis to condemn the killing of the president of the Association of Ivorians in Tunisia in an attack they described as ""racist"".

On 24 December 2018, clashes between citizens and police forces continued in the city of Jebnayna for the second day after the death of a young man in a police chase the day before. Protesters threw stones at the police station and set tires on fire. Police forces used tear gas to disperse them.

On 24 December 2018, 7 young pharmacists entered a hunger strike and sit-in at the headquarter of the Ministery of Health in Tunis to demand that the government decree regulating the opening of pharmacies in the private sector be passed. The sit-in continued for a third day on 26 December 2018.

On 24 December 2018, hunger strikers in the city of Metlaoui closed the road between Metlaoui and Tozeur by burning tires in protest against the deterioration of their health. Protesters had been on a hunger strike since a week before and the government has not yet responded to their demands, mainly for employment.

column16: AFP; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; AP
column17: On 24 December 2018, after a cameraman working for a private television channel set himself on fire, people in Kasserine burned tires, blocked roads and threw stones at the security forces. Police fired tear gas to disperse protesters. Six police forces were injured and several people were arrested.
On 24 December 2018, a group of Ivorians in Tunisia staged a sit-in outside the Mongi Slim Hospital in La Marsa to condemn the killing of the president of the Association of Ivorians in Tunisia.

On 25 December 2018, a number of employees at the Gafsa Phosphate Company held a protest in front of the company's social headquarter voicing various demands, including increases in wages and occupational safety for workers.
On 25 December 2018, a number of unemployed youths from the Souassi region held a protest in front of the headquarter of the province in Mahdia to demand employment in the Sidi El Kilani oil field.

column7: UGET: General Union of Tunisian Students
column17: On 25 December 2018, UGET organized a protest on Habib Bourguiba avenue in Tunis denouncing the deteriorating social and economic conditions and calling for a change of the government.

On 25 December 2018, protesters held a demonstration in front of the headquarter of the municipality in Al Miknasi to demand the start of the work at the phosphate mine. Protesters closed the road with tires and security forces used tear gas to disperse them.

column9: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: On 25 December 2018, clashes between demonstrators and police broke out in Foussana. Demonstrators blocked the main road. National Guard forces intervened and used tear gas after demonstrators threw stones and Molotov cocktails at the district security headquarters.

On 25 December 2018, the protesters closed the main road between Sfax and Mahdia at the Southern entrance of Jabinyanah to protest the killing of a young man who died during a security chase. One police officer was injured in the ensuing clashes.

On 25 December 2018, police clashed with protesters in Kasserine after the burial of the journalist who set himself on fire the day before. Protesters blocked the main road and set tires on fire. Tunisian police forces used tear gas to disperse them.

On or around 25 December 2018, protesters in Sidi Bouzid blocked the roads with tires and threw stones at police vehicles. Police used tear gas to disperse the protesters and arrested 40 (15 detained).
On 25 December 2018, a number of protesters, including some unemployed people and some activists, carried out a march in Douar Hicher calling for development and employment.
On or around 25 December 2018, after the announcement of the results of the recruitment campaign of the environmental company, some unemployed people staged a sit-in and continued a hunger strike.

column7: URAP: Regional Union of Agriculture and Fisheries; Farmers (Tunisia); Labour Group (Tunisia)
column17: On 25 December 2018, the Regional Union of Agriculture and Fisheries in Sidi Bouzid organized a day of anger in which farmers in the region protested against the deteriorating conditions of agriculture and the state policies targetting farmers and the agriculture sector.

column16: Al Chourouk; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse
column17: On 25 December 2018, a night protest was held by a number of youths at the western entrance of Tebourba. Protesters burned tires on the main road causing traffic disruption amid intensive police presence. They also threw stones at a train and broke its windows causing panic and fear among the passengers.

column16: Mosaique FM; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse
column17: On 25 December 2018, dozens of Sub-Saharan African students and citizens staged a protest in front of the Municipal Theater in Tunis to condemn the murder of the president of the association of Ivorians in Tunisia.

column8: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: On 26 December 2018, protests continued for the third night in various cities in Tunisia and the National Guard intervened in numerous regions. Protesters blocked the Sfax-Chebba road and security forces used tear gas to disperse them.

column8: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: On 26 December 2018, protests continued for the third night in various cities in Tunisia and the National Guard intervened in numerous regions. Protestors threw stones at the National Guard regional barracks in Thala in the governorate of Kasserine.

column8: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: On 26 December 2018, protests continued for the third night in various cities in Tunisia and the National Guard intervened in numerous regions. Protesters burned tires and threw stones at security forces in the Saida district of the northern Manouba Governorate. The National Guard used tear gas to disperse them.

column8: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: On 26 December 2018, protests continued for the third night in various cities in Tunisia and the National Guard intervened in numerous regions. Similar confrontations happened in Fouchana between protesters and the National Guard.

column8: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: On 26 December 2018, protests continued for the third night in various cities in Tunisia and the National Guard intervened in numerous regions. Protestors burned tires and closed the highway in the Tebban district of Kairouan bud fled after the National Guard intervened.

On 26 December 2018, clashes between protesters and security forces continued in Kasserine for the third consecutive night after a journalist set himself on fire. Protesters burned tires. Several arrests were made.

In the week of 23 December 2018, various cities in Kasserine including Sbeitla, Sbiba, and Feriana witnessed clashes during protests in which roads were blocked, tires were burned, and stones were thrown at security forces.

In the week of 23 December 2018, various cities in Kasserine including Sbeitla, Sbiba, and Feriana witnessed clashes during protests in which roads were blocked, tires were burned, and stones were thrown at security forces.

In the week of 23 December 2018, various cities in Kasserine including Sbeitla, Sbiba, and Feriana witnessed clashes during protests in which roads were blocked, tires were burned, and stones were thrown at security forces.
On 26 December 2018, a number of unemployed young people from Bou Hajla in Kairouan State closed highway no. 2 and burned tires to demand employment. Police forces intervened and opened the road.

On 26 December 2018, clashes between protesters and police forces in Jabinyanah continued. Protesters threw stones at the police forces who responded with tear gas. Two policemen were also injured when intervening to prevent a protester from setting himself on fire.
On 26 December 2018, the Foussena police station was attacked with Molotov cocktails thrown by some protesters. Police arrested several people and seized Molotov cocktails.

On 26 December 2018, lawyers organized a sit-in in front of the Court of First Instance in Kasserine to protest against the Finance Act of 2019 and also show their solidarity with the protesters and blame the government for the deterioration of the situation in the region.

On 26 December 2018, a military cell affiliated with the Soldiers of the Caliphate in Sfax was detected and dismantled by the National Unit for Investigation of Terrorist Crimes and Organized Crimes of Tunisia. Three individuas were arrested in the operation and explosive precursors were seized.
On or around 27 December 2018, soldiers were wounded by IED/mine detonation at Jebel Mghila in Kasserine.
On 27 December 2018, farmers staged a protest and marched toward the gorvernorate headquarter in El Kef to voice their social and economic demands.

On 27 December 2018, several protesters closed the intersection in front of the headquarter of the Kasserine governorate to demand employment. They threw stones and Molotov cocktails at police, police responded with tear gas.
On 27 December 2018, the regional coordination of the Popular Front in Gafsa organized a protest in the center of the city against the government policies and the economic situation in the country.
On 27 December 2018, clashes broke out between protesters and security forces in El Kef. Protesters closed highway No. 5 and set tires on fire. Security agents used tear gas to disperse them.
On 27 December 2018, a demonstration was held in Kairouan in protest against the economic and development situation in the region.
On 27 December 2018, a number of unemployed people in Redeyef closed the road at the entrance to the city. They also stopped a number of buses and trucks to demand employment.

column7: UMGSP: Union of General Practitioners in Public Health; Labour Group (Tunisia)
column17: On 27 December 2018, the Union of General Practitioners organized a protest in front of the headquarter of the Ministry of Public Health to call for the drafting of an organic law on the health sector and improvement in their working conditions.

column7: URAP: Regional Union of Agriculture and Fisheries; Farmers (Tunisia); Labour Group (Tunisia)
column17: On 27 December 2018, farmers responded to the call of the Regional Union of Agriculture and Fisheries and staged a protest through the streets of Siliana toward the headquarter of the governorate to raise several social and economic demands.

On 28 December 2018, the workers of the ETEP company staged a protest with the presence of the local trade union in front of the company's headquarter in Ras Ajdir in Medenine to voice their demands and call for their labor rights.
On 28 December 2018, a number of taxi drivers blocked the road in front of the El Hamma municipality to protest the denial of their right to new licenses.

On 28 December 2018, a number of civil society activists held a protest in Kasserine demanding the government's attention to the region and the implementation of its promises over the years following the revolution.

On 28 December 2018, a group of young people clashed with the police in Cite Ettahrir. They set tires on fire, tried to close the road, and threw stones at the police who responded with tear gas to disperse them.

On 28 December 2018, a group of young people clashed with the police in Intilaka. They set tires on fire, tried to close the road, and threw stones at the police who responded with tear gas to disperse them.
On 28 December 2018, some residents protested against traffic accidents caused by smuggling trucks in Nasrallah after the death of a teacher in an accident. Protesters clashed with security forces.

On 28 December 2018, night protests broke out in Cite Ennour neighborhood in Kasserine. Protesters burned tires on the main street, closed the entrance to the city center and threw stones at police forces who responded with tear gas to disperse them.

column8: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column16: Tunisie Numerique; Nessma; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse
column17: On 28 December 2018, there were clashes between the youth and the National Guard in Cite Ettadhamen. Protesters burned tires, blocked roads and threw stones at police who tried to disperse them. Protesters also ransacked ATMs, attacked banks and tried to smash surveillance cameras. Several arrests were made.

On 28 December 2018, in parallel with the holding of the negotiation session between the government and the Tunisian General Union of Labor, civil servants held a protest in Kasbah to call on the government to respond to their demands.
On 28 December 2018, a number of African students held a protest in Mahdia to condemn the killing of the president of the Association of Ivorians in Tunisia.

column8: Military Forces of Tunisia (2014-2019) National Guard
column17: On 29 December 2018, clashes between National Guard and protesters in Cite Ettadhamen continued. Protesters burned tires and security forces used tear gas to disperse them.
On 29 December 2018, a protest was held in Hammam Chott in which protesters blocked the road and damaged the property of others. Several arrests were made.

Reported on 29 December 2018, a number of unemployed people in Redeyef held a sit-in after the announcement of the results of the recruitment campaign of the environmental company, disrupting the services of the municipality.

On 30 December 2018, local civil society groups and the young recruits at the phosphate mine in Al Miknasi held a protest to demand the start of the operation of the region's phosphate mine so that the youths who had been recruited more than a year ago could start working in the mine.
On 30 December 2018, protests continued in Cite Ettadhamen. A number of youths who set tires on fire were dispersed by security forces.

On or around 30 December 2018, workers of the textile factory in Menzel Chaker organized a demonstration in front of the governorate headquarter in Sfax to protest against the closure of the factory and their unemployment.

On 30 December 2018, protesters blocked the GP1 road in Bou Argoub and set tires on fire to protest against the release of a driver who killed one of their relatives in a road accident three days ago.

On 30 December 2018, a number of civil society actors as part of the Coordination of the Environment and Development organized a protest in Sfax to demand from the City Council to adopt a decision prohibiting any industry of phosphates and sulfur and any circulation of trucks for the transport of these products inside the city.

column7: SNFSI: National Union of Internal Security Forces; Labour Group (Tunisia)
column17: On 31 December 2018, the Regional Union of Internal Security Forces in the mining basin area of Gafsa organized a protest in front of the security and national guard areas in Metlaoui to condemn the increase in organized crime and to demand for an improvement in their working conditions.

On 31 December 2018, protests resumed in Jabinyanah in solidarity with a young man who died in a police chase the week before. Clashes were reported between the residents and the security forces who used tear gas to disperse the protesters.
On 31 December 2018, civil servants in Tamerza organized a protest in front of the municipality to demand social welfare for the family of one of their colleagues who was killed in a work accident.

On 31 December 2018, poultry farmers held a protest in front of the Regional Trade Department in Sfax to protest against the raid on the commercial interests of some of the poultry farms in the area and the seizure of some quantities of eggs.

On 2 January 2019, doctors, pharmacists and dentists carried out a protest in front of the Ministry of Health at the invitation of UGTT to denounce the conditions for granting of licenses for pharmacies and demand an increase in their salaries.

On 2 January 2019, secondary education teachers sarted an open sit-in at the office of the Regional Directorate of Education in Mahdia in protest against the sacking of a director of a secondary institute in the Sherban region and the suspension of the salary of another teacher. The sit-in was continuing as of two days later.
On the week of 2 January 2019, protesters started a sit-in in front of the hearquarters of the municipality in Bir Ali Ben Khalifa to demand employment and development for the city and its people.

column16: Twitter; Tunisie Numerique; Agence Tunis Afrique Presse

On 21 October 2020, farmers barricaded roads with stones and barricades in Kairouan (Kairouan Sud, Kairouan) to denounce shortage in the provision of farming fertilizers. [size=no report]

On 21 October 2020, a group of athletes and presidents of sports clubs protested in Kairouan (Kairouan Sud, Kairouan) to denounce the decision of local authorities to establish a field hospital for coronavirus victims inside a public sports hall. [size=no report]

On 21 October 2020, family members of a deceased coronavirus victim protested inside the local hospital in Kasserine (Ezzouhour, Kasserine) to denounce the dissapearance of the victim's body from the hospital's morgue. [size=no report]

On 22 October 2020, contractual workers in public institutions aged between forty-five and fifty-five years barricaded roads with burning tires in Menzel Bouzaiane (Sidi Bou Zid) to denounce the agreement between the Tunisian General Labour Union and government authorities to recruit all contractual workers aged under forty-five years in public institutions and discharge contractual workers above that age threshold for a financial compensation. [size=no report]

column7: Labour Group (Tunisia); UTT: Tunisian Workers Union
column17: On 22 October 2020, contractual workers in public institutions aged between forty-five and fifty-five years and affiliated with the UTT protested in front of the headquarters of the Tunisian Workers Union in Gafsa (Gafsa Sud, Gafsa) to denounce the agreement between the Tunisian General Labour Union and government authorities to recruit all contractual workers aged under forty-five years in public institutions and discharge contractual workers above that age threshold for a financial compensation. [size=no report]

On 22 October 2020, unemployed graduate sports teachers protested in front of the governorate headqaurters in Sfax (Sfax Medina, Sfax) to demand their permanent recruitment in public sports and education institutions. [size=no report]

On 22 October 2020, workers and employees in the Amal Association of Disabled Persons protested in front of the association headquarters in Beja (Beja Sud, Beja) to demand financial support from government authorities against a drop in donations and funding during the outbreak of coronavirus. [size=no report]

On 22 October 2020, contractual workers in public institutions aged between forty-five and fifty-five years protested in front of the governorate headquarters in Beja (Beja Sud, Beja) to denounce the agreement between the Tunisian General Labour Union and government authorities to recruit all contractual workers aged under forty-five years in public institutions and discharge contractual workers above that age threshold for a financial compensation. [size=no report]

column7: Students (Tunisia); UGTE: General Tunisian Union of Students
column17: On 22 October 2020, students, supported by the General Tunisian Union of Students, protested in front of the governorate headquarters in Sfax (Sfax Medina, Sfax) to demand the reopening of university restaurants and to denounce the absence of strict protective measures against coronavirus in universities and students' dormitories. [size=no report]

On 22 October 2020, contractual workers in public institutions aged between forty-five and fifty-five years protested in front of the governorate headquarters in Kairouan (Kairouan Sud, Kairouan) to denounce the agreement between the Tunisian General Labour Union and government authorities to recruit all contractual workers aged under forty-five years in public institutions and discharge contractual workers above that age threshold for a financial compensation. [size=no report]

On 22 October 2020, workers and owners of traditional hammams protested in front of the governorate headquarters in Kairouan (Kairouan Sud, Kairouan) to demand from the local authorities to issue permissions for the reopening of hammams that were closed due to the outbreak of coronavirus in the region. [size=no report]

On 22 October 2020, contractual workers in public institutions aged between forty-five and fifty-five years blocked roads in Metlaoui (Gafsa) to denounce the agreement between the Tunisian General Labour Union and government authorities to recruit all contractual workers aged under forty-five years in public institutions and discharge contractual workers above that age threshold for a financial compensation. [size=no report]

On 22 October 2020, family members of a deceased coronavirus victim barricaded roads with burning tires in Mejen Bel Abbes (Mejel Belabbes, Kasserine) to denounce the dissapearance of the victim's body from the local hospital's morgue. [size=no report]

column7: Labour Group (Tunisia); UGTT: Tunisian General Labour Union
column17: On 22 October 2020, contractual workers in public institutions aged between forty-five and fifty-five years and affiliated with the UGTT protested in front of the headquarters of the Tunisian General Labour Union in Bab el Bhar (Bab Bhar, Tunis) to denounce the agreement with government authorities to recruit all contractual workers aged under forty-five years in public institutions and discharge contractual workers above that age threshold for a financial compensation. [size=no report]

column7: Health Workers (Tunisia); UGTT: Tunisian General Labour Union
column17: On 22 October 2020, contractual health workers affiliated with the UGTT protested in front of the headquarters of the Tunisian General Labour Union in Bab el Bhar (Bab Bhar, Tunis) to demand their permanent recruitment in public health institutions. [size=no report]

On 22 October 2020, farmers barricaded roads with stones and barricades for the second day in a row in Kairouan (Kairouan Sud, Kairouan) to denounce shortage in the provision of farming fertilizers. [size=no report]

column7: Labour Group (Tunisia); UGTT: Tunisian General Labour Union
column17: On 22 October 2020, workers for the public Environment and Gardinage Company, supported by the Tunisian General Labour Union, protested in front of the governorate headquarters in Tataouine (Tataouine Nord, Tataouine) to demand the payment of their salaries for the past two months. [size=no report]

On 23 October 2020, a group of youth protested and burned the French flag in Az Zahrouni (Sidi Hassine, Tunis) to denounce the perceived negative statements of French authorities supporting blasphemous pictures against the prophet Mohammed. [size=no report]
On 23 October 2020, teachers protested in a high school in El Haouaria (Haouaria, Nabeul) to denounce the lack of equipment and refurbished spaces in the school. [size=no report]

On 23 October 2020, contractual workers in public institutions aged between forty-five and fifty-five years protested in Mezzouna (Mazzouna, Sidi Bou Zid) to denounce the agreement between the Tunisian General Labour Union and government authorities to recruit all contractual workers aged under forty-five years in public institutions and discharge contractual workers above that age threshold for a financial compensation. [size=no report]

On 23 October 2020, contractual workers in public institutions aged between forty-five and fifty-five years protested in Jabinyanah (Jebeniana, Sfax) to denounce the agreement between the Tunisian General Labour Union and government authorities to recruit all contractual workers aged under forty-five years in public institutions and discharge contractual workers above that age threshold for a financial compensation. [size=no report]

column7: Health Workers (Tunisia); UGTT: Tunisian General Labour Union
column17: On 23 October 2020, contractual workers in public institutions aged between forty-five and fifty-five years and affiliated with the UGTT blocked roads in front of the headquarters of the Tunisian General Labour Union in Siliana (Siliana Nord, Siliana) to denounce the agreement with government authorities to recruit all contractual workers aged under forty-five years in public institutions and discharge contractual workers above that age threshold for a financial compensation. [size=no report]

On 23 October 2020, contractual workers in public institutions aged between forty-five and fifty-five years protested for the second day in a row in front of the governorate headquarters in Beja (Beja Sud, Beja) to denounce the agreement between the Tunisian General Labour Union and government authorities to recruit all contractual workers aged under forty-five years in public institutions and discharge contractual workers above that age threshold for a financial compensation. [size=no report]

On 23 October 2020, family members of a deceased coronavirus victim stormed the local hospital in Sbeitla (Kasserine) and attacked health workers to forcibly take out the body of the deceased victim from the hospital's morgue. [size=no report]

column7: Labour Group (Tunisia); Recruitement Is My Right Movement
column17: On 23 October 2020, unemployed graduates, supported by the Recruitement Is My Right Movement, protested in Jendouba (Jendouba Nord, Jendouba) to demand that government authorities issue an executive order to implement a law approved by the Parliament on the recruitment of graduates who have been unemployed for more than ten years into the public sector. [size=no report]

On 23 October 2020, contractual workers in public institutions aged between forty-five and fifty-five years protested in front of the delegation headquarters in Ain Jaloulah (Oueslatia, Kairouan) to denounce the agreement between the Tunisian General Labour Union and government authorities to recruit all contractual workers aged under forty-five years in public institutions and discharge contractual workers above that age threshold for a financial compensation. [size=no report]

On 23 October 2020, workers at a commercial space protested in Sousse (Sousse Medina, Sousse) to denounce the lack of rapid intervention from public health workers that led to the death of their colleague from coronavirus. [size=no report]

On 23 October 2020, family members of the street trader killed last week by municipal police during the bulldozing of an illegal cigarette kiosk barricaded roads with burning tires in Sbeitla (Kasserine) to demand the prosecution of those responsible for the incident. [size=no report]

On 23 October 2020, football supporters of the Chebba Sports Club organized a car protest toward the governorate headquarters in Mahdia (Mahdia) to denounce the decision of the Tunisian Football League to ban their club from national competitions. [size=no report]

column7: Labour Group (Tunisia); UTT: Tunisian Workers Union
column17: On 24 October 2020, contractual workers in public institutions aged between forty-five and fifty-five years and affiliated with the UGTT protested and tried to hang themselves in front of the headquarters of the Tunisian General Labour Union in Bab el Bhar (Bab Bhar, Tunis) to denounce the agreement with government authorities to recruit all contractual workers aged under forty-five years in public institutions and discharge contractual workers above that age threshold for a financial compensation. [size=no report]
300 - 400 bibanja owners (tenants) in Mukono district last evening blocked the Mukono-Kayunga road in protest against their imminent eviction by a landlord.
Two excavators worth millions of shillings were set ablaze yesterday morning by a group of irate Tabliq youth protesting the demolition of part of Nakasero mosque.
Thugs attacked the home of an Asian entrepreneur in Rugazi armed with knives, pangas and a hammer.
Reports of recent clashes between Batwa and Bakiga ethnic groups in Nyanamo trading centre. Date not specified.
A clash broke out between political opponents at a local meeting in Masaka in the run-up to national elections. Riot police became involved and quelled the disturbance.
Two journalists were attacked by supporters of the NRM while covering an opposition presidential candidatess campaign rally in Lango.

Change to armed group: Uganda's electoral commission admitted for the first time on Wednesday that political parties in the east African country have formed militias to protect their turf ahead of the upcoming presidential election.
Two radio journalists were assaulted by NRM MP, Sauda Namagwa, in Masaka when attempting to get information about the electoral contest in the region.
A Ugandan gay rights activist with Sexual Minorities Uganda who late last year was pictured and named in a homophobic tabloid has been murdered at his home outside Kampala.
Scuffles broke out between clergy and mourners at the funeral of murdered gay rights activist, David Kato, when the presiding priest presented a sermon on the evils of homosexuality.
Two suspected armed gunmen were shot and killed by Uganda Police Forces Rapid Response Unit operatives in Mbarara. The suspects died during an exchange of fire with RRU officials.
Hundreds of youths walked three kilometres from Buganda Road to Kololo independence grounds to call for peace before, during and after the elections on February 18.
Property destruction: The Electoral Commission (EC) witnessed an attack by Kiboko squad members on two polling stations in Bukoto South.

Violent clashes broke out between FDC supporters and the police when the former were found campaigning after the campaign cut-off point and police attempted to arrest them. 26 supporters of the FDC were arrested.

Movement of forces: Reports of massive deployment of armed police in Northern Uganda town of Gulu in anticipation of potential violence surrounding upcoming national elections. Civilians described the deployment as intimidating.

FDC supporters in Iganga Municipality housing estate detained eight Policemen and their patrol pick-up for about four hours on Thursday night. The FDC supporters also smashed the windscreen of the vehicle.
Independent political candidate supporters were involved in violent clashes with NRM supporters in Tororo and Malaba, sparking 42 arrests.
Independent political candidate supporters were involved in violent clashes with NRM supporters in Tororo and Malaba, sparking 42 arrests.
In Kamod, Serere district, Cpl. John Francis Olupot, was cut on the head as he tried to diffuse tension between NRM and FDC supporters shortly after midnight.
Violence erupted at Elgon View Primary School polling station in Tororo Municipality after supporters of incumbent MP, Sanjay Tanna, and arch-rival Apollo Ofwono Yeri, engaged in a fight.
Buliisa residents were arrested after they whipped people in Kalengejja. They reportedly targeted those who did not support Birahwaa.
The brother of incumbent candidate and minister, sustained a broken arm after he was stoned during a scuffle in Namisambya Primary School between supporters of two different camps of the NRM.
32 people were arrested in Lango for intimidating and torturing opponents supporters on election day. Political affiliations not mentioned.

A television journalist based in Mbale was beaten by a mob of NRM supporters when covering voting irregularities in Khamoto trading centre. Alleged military forces clad in civilian clothing were reported to have assisted the mob.
Soldiers shot freelance journalist Julius Odeke near Bugusege in Eastern Uganda while covering electoral violence in the East of the country.
In Masaka, DP chairman was beaten up after he tried to stop people he identified as NRM supporters and soldiers who were giving out sugar to the voters.

Protests broke out at Kyengera polling station when ballot boxes without seals were brought from the Electoral Commission. Voters called for a boycott of the electoral process until new boxes were brought.

Six DP supporters in Masaka sustained injuries after engaging in scuffles with the military and anti-riot police. The group, led by Jude Mbabaali, the defeated DP candidate for Bukoto Central, began a demonstration from Kabonera Trading Centre and was heading to the Electoral Commission offices in Masaka town to petition Mr Edward Ssekandis victory

The police in Kitgum district [northern Uganda] on Monday stopped a demonstration by members of the Uganda Peoples Congress (UPC) party. The demonstrators, numbering about 15 and clad in the UPC party T-shirts, carried placards and marched through Kitgum town before they were stopped by police near Boma grounds. The youth, however, tried to resist claiming that they had the right to contest the results.
Movement of forces: Heavy troop deployment in Mbale following election irregularities across the country.
Movement of forces: Reports that Al-Shabab militants have crossed into Uganda, allegedly focusing an attack on Mbuya, Kampala, lead to a rise in the terror alert level.

Stick-wielding thugs with links to the Kampala mayoral candidate for the ruling National Resistance Movement (NRM) party, Peter Ssematimba, assaulted six journalists at the Kakeeka polling station, in Rubaga Parish, in Kampalas Lubaga division. There are indications that the hooligans formulated a plan to beat up journalists since they called media houses to say that Ssematimba was going to vote at the Kakeeka polling station at 10:00 a.m. and they requested a media presence.

Four journalists and voters were attacked by stick-wielding Kiboko Squad at the Super FM radio station in Rubaga, Kampala. Police intervened to assist them. Party affiliation of attackers not mentioned.
Movement of forces: Heavy troop deployment throughout Kampala following opposition leader, Kizza Besigyes, call for protests against the outcome of the national elections.

An anti-riot police official told Dow Jones Newswires that dozens of protesters were arrested early Wednesday after they attempted to block a road to a busy market area in the city. Police fired teargas to dispers protesters.

Opposition supporters in the capitals Kiseka market attacked several people wearing yellow clothes -- the colour of President Yoweri Musevenis party -- after police declared a protest called by some opposition leaders illegal.

Police forces halted and dispersed opposition protests in Jinja, as UPC supporters claimed vote irregularities allowed NRM candidate to win in national elections. The UPC candidate sustained injuries.

240 Senior Four students took part in a strike and a night riot at the school during which classrooms and dormitories were destroyed. The strike was in response to punishments for students caught loitering in Mbarara town.
Students demonstrating at Mutesa I Royal University in Buganda over university administration and poor hygiene have assaulted two journalists invited to cover the protests by the Students Guild.
Students demonstrated at Mutesa I Royal University in Buganda over university administration and poor hygiene.

Two journalists reported injured in demonstration organized by opposition political parties in Jinja town, Eastern Uganda. Journalists who were at the scenereported that anti-riot police were targeting television camera persons and photojournalists who were in front of the demonstrators.

Students of Gulu School of Clinical Officers on Monday boycotted their end of semester examinations, citing irregularities in the new examinations system. Heavy police presence was deployed in anticipation of violence. Calm was only restored in the campus after a meeting between the administration, students leaders and representatives of other stakeholders.
Supporters of Independent Mayoral candidate, Erias Lukwago, were scattered from gathering publicly celebrating victory by forces firing teargas and live rounds over their heads in downtown Kampala.

column7: NOTU: National Organisation of Trade Unions
column17: Management of Tilda denied NOTU officials access to the company premises to conduct a meeting with workers, which led to the deployment of riot police to quell disturbances and clashes.
Freelance journalist assaulted by NRM Kanungu Town Councillor, Emmy Magezi Byarugaba, while covering his trial for assault charges.
A lynch mob of more than 50 people beat to death an alleged thief in a suburb of Kampala.
Police forces shot and killed two men in a lynch mob involved in the beating to death of a suspected thief in the Kampala suburb.
Police in Kampala halted a demonstration held by hundreds of Ugandans and African immigrants in support of Moammar Gadhafi, allegedly headed towards the US and western embassies.
Scuffles broke out between protesting students and university staff at Mutendwe campus. Protests were over space constraints when making room for new students.
A reporter covering the clashes which broke out at Mutendwe campus was arrested and assaulted by police officers.
Protesters rioted in response to the arrest of opposition leader, Kizza Besigye, to which police responded by firing into crowds. At least two protesters injured in the shoot-out.
School students strike over administration in schools across Uganda. Police brought in to quell disruption. The strike degenerated into running battles with police.
A 16-year-old student of Bubaare Secondary School in Kabale District was on Monday shot dead as the police battled to quell a strike by students.

The Ugandan opposition began a protest in the capital city of Kampala Monday against sky-rocketing food and fuel prices, in an attempt to press the government to act against runaway inflation. Police arrested opposition leader Kizza Besigye for leading the demonstration.
Local police battled opposition supporters in the provincial towns of Jinja and Masaka, using teargas to disperse demonstrations held in solidarity with those in Kampala.
Local police battled opposition supporters in the provincial towns of Jinja and Masaka, using teargas to disperse demonstrations held in solidarity with those in Kampala.
Demonstrators sought shelter from police in a local hospital, where police then fired tear gas into the hospital indiscriminately.
Reports that soldiers shot indiscriminately in the Kampala Road area, killing one man hiding from the soldiers and wounding others.
Reports that an off-duty, unarmed soldier was attacked by a mob in a residential area of Gulu following the days unrest and alleged abuses by security forces.
Reports that soldiers stopped and searched traders uninvolved in demonstrations and shot indiscriminately. One trader shot in the back and killed.

Clashes broke out after police blocked an opposition demonstration, with over thirty demonstrators being hospitalised for injuries and gun shot wounds. Among them was Kizza Besigye, opposition leader, shot in the hand during the clash. Levels of violence at riots escalated in response.
Local police battled opposition supporters in the provincial town of Mbale, using teargas to disperse demonstrations held in solidarity with those in Kampala.
Reports by two women that they were raped by soldiers on the night of Gulus demonstrations and unrest.

column7: FDC: Forum for Democratic Change; Women (Uganda)
column17: Police fired on opposition demonstrators, shooting a pregnant woman in the stomach and leaving her in grave condition.

Residents of Gulu town protesting the arrest of district chairman Norbert Mao over the walk-to-work demonstration have come under heavy gunfire and tear-gassing by both soldiers and police. Residents are fighting back by pelting the security operatives with stones, and are burning car tyres and any combustible material on the roads to halt the militaries.

Ugandan opposition resumed protests against rising food and fuel prices in an attempt to press the government to act on inflation. The protest was intercepted by heavily armed anti-riot police, using tear gas and firing into the air to disperse protesters.
Reports that soldiers shot indiscriminately in rush hour Gulu traffic forcing drivers from their cars and beating them.

Fresh battles pitted Ugandan police against students in Kampala at Makerere University over a proposal to double tuition fees. Police in anti-riot gear backed by the military ring-fenced Makereres main campus.
An opposition official said police used tear gas against several hundred people taking part in a march in Rukungiri, the western Uganda hometown of opposition leader Kizza Besigye.
Some 200 fishermen at Bugonga landing site in Entebbe at the weekend staged a demonstration protesting a government move to evict them.
Security forces clashed with opposition demonstrators leading to fresh riots in the capital. Police fired tear gas and live rounds to disperse demonstrators. One protester killed.
Opposition leader, Kizza Besigye, arrested as he set out on a walk to work demonstration from his home in Kampala.
WBS TV cameraman Francis Mukasa was beaten at Makindye Ssabagabo court while covering protests following the arrest of the Kampala mayor-elect Ssalongo Erias Lukwago.

A Radio One journalist, was seriously roughed up by military personnel at Wampeewo, from where he was relaying live scenes of gunfire. Muyinda was properly identified as a journalist because he was in his radio station jacket.

In Masaka district, the Uganda Peoples Defence Force (UPDF - Uganda armed forces) and the police used violence to calm the protesters (coded separately). In the process, four journalists were targeted.
Police cleared protesters who were blocking and closing the Masaka highway in the regional coffee transport hub.

Following fresh walk to work protests, police fired tear gas and stones were hurled back at them in a brief clash during which Besigye, who stood against Museveni in February elections, was bundled into a police van.
Police battled protesters engaged in walk to work demonstrations with live ammunition, shooting and killing three demonstrators.
A child is shot and killed in the chaos surrounding demonstrations in Masaka. Two adults were rushed to hospital with multiple gunshot wounds.
Fresh violence erupted surrounding protests in Masaka as security forces battled to control demonstrators.
Thirty residents of Luweero District were arrested after leading a procession to take food to imprisoned opposition leader, Kizza Besigye.
The arrest of opposition leader, Kizza Besigye, sparked riots in Kampala city centre. Police fired live rounds and teargas to disperse protesters.

Opposition leader, Kizza Besigye, was arrested as he set out on a walk-to-work demonstration from his home in Kasangati. A crowd of several hundred supporters formed a barrier around Besigye, but police smashed his car window and fired tear gas into the vehicle, breaking the standoff.

Two people were killed on Thursday as armed raiders stole more than 180 animals from Kuura grazing zone in Marsabit North District. The victims, a herdsman and a raider, were killed in a two-hour gun battle between the camel herders and the rustlers suspected to be from Loyangalani District.

Rioters setting fire to tyres and building road blocks in Kampala clashed with police forces firing teargas and live rounds. Vendors were shot in Owino Market where there was allegedly no rioting. One killed.
Uniformed soldiers reportedly entered a car lot and beat workers indiscriminately with batons and wire. A worker trying to escape was shot in the back while fleeing and died instantly.
Soldiers patrolling in armored personnel carriers shot indiscriminately at civilians outside on the streets; a landlord collecting rent from tenants was shot and killed by uniformed police.
Security forces allegedly shot indiscriminately in the residential area of Bwaise in Kampala, One resident was shot in the back and killed when he emerged from his home to see what was happening.
A taxi driver was shot and killed by plain clothes security operates when he fled from indiscriminate firing in the residential Namasuba area.

Rioters setting fire to tyres and building road blocks in Kampala clashed with police forces firing teargas and live rounds. Vendors were shot in Nakivubo Market in response to clashes between police and vendors. One vendor killed, several injured.
Reports that police broke into houses and shot residents indiscriminately in Kibe Zone, resulting in several hospitalisations.
Witnesses reported police in camouflage uniforms shot three individuals indiscriminately from an armoured personnel carrier.

Supporters celebrated as opposition leader Norbert Mao was released following a fortnight in prison. Supporters walked towards Kampala city centre, but were intercepted by riot police at Lugogo and dispersed by tear gas and rubber bullets.
Reports that Radio Simba journalist was targeted by riot police while covering the dispersal of protesters in Lugogo.
Norbert Mao arrested during walk to work protests in the Kampala suburb.
Smaller protests than previous weeks took place with a lighter security presence and little violence.
Hundreds of women demonstrated in Ugandas capital on Monday over high food prices and brutal tactics employed by police during recent political rallies.
Unidentified assailants attacked New Vision journalist Goodluck Musinguizi and set fire to his home in Rushaki war, Kabale.

column7: DP: Democratic Party; FDC: Forum for Democratic Change; UPC: Uganda Peoples Congress
column17: Opposition politicians Norbert Mao and Muhammed Kibirige were arrested after they were arrested as they tried to access the Constitution Square in Kampala to conduct a rally. The politicians were part of a larger group that attempted to access the square in the heart of the city for a rally even after the police had insisted the area was out of bounds. Police used water canons to disperse crowds.

Crowds demonstrated calling for the return of Kizza Besigye, currently receiving medical attention in Nairobi for injuries sustained during demonstrations. The crowds demonstration coincided with Musevenis seaerinig-in ceremony.
At least two journalists reported being harassed and targeted by police while covering the dispersal of crowds in Constitution Square.

At least ten journalists reported being harassed, targeted and assaulted by members of the police and security forces while trying to cover the return of opposition leader, Kizza Besigye. Several reported showing their press identification and being assaulted anyway.
Police opened fire on rioting crowds after they attacked a car carrying Nigerias President Goodluck Jonathon, who had attended Musevenis inauguration. At least one person killed.
At least 10 Ugandan and foreign journalists were physically attacked by soldiers while covering opposition leader Kizza Besigyes return to Uganda from Kenya.
Huge crowds gathered to welcome back opposition leader Kizza Besigye on his flight from Kenya. Ugandan security forces clashed with opposition supporters; shots fired to disperse demonstrators.

Ugandan opposition supporters hurled stones at a car carrying Nigerias President Goodluck Jonathan as he visited the country to attend President Yoweri Musevenis swearing-in ceremony in the capital. The Ugandan security forces fired at the protesters, killing one person. Security forcers and opposition forces clash on a bridge in another area of town.

column7: FDC: Forum for Democratic Change; Journalists (Uganda)
column17: Police and soldiers threw up a roadblock outside Entebbe, preventing opposition supporters and journalists from reaching the airport when opposition leader Besigye arrived.

Following attempts to disperse crowds welcoming back opposition leader Kizza Besigye, clashes spread from Entebbe to central Kampala. Police fired live rounds, rubber bullets and tear gas at supporters. Police also intercepted Besigye on his way to Kampala and prevented him from proceeding. The standoff degenerated into a riot.

Besigye convoy of only three vehicles reach Kitoro trading centre following clashes near Kitubulu. People have waited behind buildings after being chased by police. Shots fired, the crowd responded by throwing stones at police.

Opposition protesters gather along a road in to support their leader Kizza Besigye, who is arriving from Kenya and traveling by motorcade after he was kicked off an airplane in Kenya. Police and other security forces attack supporters along the road, caning them. Military police mounts two road blocks one at the UN base and the second at Kitubulu centre where more crowds are waiting for the opposition leader.
Robert Mugabe was allegedly caught up in violent clashes by opposition supporters in Uganda, when protesters stoned his convoy after he attended the inauguration of President Museveni.
Police forces fire colored tear gas at commodity protesters in an effort to disperse them. Leaders of the FDC vow to return Monday for continued protests.

Workers at Kakira Sugar Factory went on a sit down strike on 13 May. The workers had put down their tools protesting against low wages and arrest of their colleagues who were also participating in the protest. They attempted to set the sugar cane plantations ablaze but police responded on time to arrest 23 of them.
The police stop opposition leader Besiye as he leaves his house and threaten him with the options of ""preventive arrest"" or returning home, believing he would begin another large scale protest.
The body of the alleged army dissident, suspected to have been among leaders of [rebel] peoples Redemption Army (PRA) by security sources in Uganda, was found dumped at his home.
A guard to the chief of defense forces has shot dead two unarmed civilians and injured another after a disagreement following a traffic incident.
Security forces abduct a journalist and hold him for two weeks on suspicion of terrorism.

Opposition protesters gather to hold a vigil for a toddler killed by security forces in April 2011 and to demand lower food prices. Police fire tear gas and rubber bullets disperse the crowd. Government officials refer to opposition protesters as militants,

Non-violent activity: The Ugandan police again surrounded the residence of main opposition leader, Kizza Besigye, in a move that officials from his party say is an attempt to prevent him from participating in protests against rising food and fuel prices.
Police fired water cannons, tear gas and pink dye at opposition leaders and their supporters to break up a rally in memory of 10 people killed in a crackdown on protests in April.

Mourners and protesters, including the FDC party, gathers to pay remembrance to protesters who were attacked and killed earlier in the year were attacked by police themselves, who used water cannons and teargas against them.
Ugandan army kills 6 suspected cattle thieves in two separate clashes.
SPLA soldiers cross the border into northern Uganda, abduct 50 farmers, then release them.

column7: FDC: Forum for Democratic Change; A4C: Activists for Change Group
column17: Police fire tear gas to disperse ""walk to work"" food price opposition protesters in downtown Kampala. Protesters respond with stones. 40 arrested. Kizza Besigye, the leader of the opposition, has largely stayed away from the gatherings.

Protests continue into their second day, Ugandan police fired tear gas at rock-throwing protesters (organized by A4C) and briefly detained a top opposition leader during renewed demonstrations over rising food and fuel prices. Days later they place the opposition leader under house arrest and two of his aids where charged with treason.

column7: FDC: Forum for Democratic Change; A4C: Activists for Change Group
column17: Opposition protests hold a ""walk to work"" rally, no police intervention reported.
Arrests: Ingrid Turinawe, chairperson of The Forum for Democratic Change (FDC) Womens League, was arrested by police and charged with treason.
Ugandan traders blockaded several streets in the capital to protest at lengthening power blackouts they say are crippling businesses around the country.
Police fired teargas at residents protesting the disrepair of a road in suburban Kampala.

The editor of Rwandas Inyenyeri news, Charles Ingabire, who had sought refuge in Uganda for political reasons, has been shot dead at a Kampala pub. It is unclear if the murder was political or random.

Anti-riot police fought running battles in an attempt to disperse hundreds of protesters angered by power outages that have hit the East African nation in recent weeks. The rioters blocked the road leading to a major airport.

Police shoot and kill a 17-year-old boy. Issa Ssemugwe, 17, died on the way to Mulago Hospital after he was allegedly shot by a police officer who was trying to quell a crowd that was allegedly blocking the arrest of their colleagues on robbery charges. Five officers were arrested in the following days.

column7: FDC: Forum for Democratic Change; A4C: Activists for Change Group; Students (Uganda)
column17: Police Wednesday morning deployed heavily at Makerere University to block opposition party (FDC) students from matching to Luzira prison to demand the release of those charged with treason.
Armed men attack Christian pastor with acid. The attackers yelled ""Allahu akhbar"" immediately before the attack.
Weapons Seizure: Cache of weaponry discovered in several Ugandan villages
Journalist beaten by police for photographing scuffle between officers and residents

column6: ADF-NALU: Allied Democratic Forces-National Army for the Liberation of Uganda

South Sudanese stormed the police station in Olego, near Atiak, to demand the release of a Ugandan who hit a South Sudanese girl. Two South Sudanese were arrested. Reportedly, one South Sudanese was SPLA and holding a gun for intimidation.
Security guards for Saracen Ltd. rioted for better salaries. Police intervened.
2 Cattle traders were shot on their way back from the market by robbers on the Kyankwanzi-Hoima highway.
A robbery at a store in Kakindo left two people dead.
Police fought with armed robbers who had AK 47s. 1 person was arrested.
Armed gunmen robbed two NGO workers.
A mob attacked casual laborers in Mubende, injuring 2 people. The riots were over land.
In a second wave of riots over land, an armed mob attacked laborers. Police intervened and arrested 35 people.

Recruitment: Security chiefs in Sembabule are concerned that M23 is recruiting in the district. In addition, it was reported that people are being trafficked from Budaka, Kibuku, and Pallisa. Police have rescued Busoga children from being sent into the conflict.
A farmer was killed by an unknown group
A man was shot by private security forces. The man who was shot was suspected to be a thief.
Police fired teargas at student demonstrators who wre contaminating food with soap and urine to protest an increase in meal fees.

column17: Agreement: M23 re-entered Uganda to resume peace talks.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: DRC Military fired on the town of Maziba from an aircraft while trying to suppress M23. 4 Ugandans were killed.
Students demonstrated for better facilities and timely release of grades.
Students protested the lack of teaching staff at Kyambogo University. Police intervened and fired teargas at the protesters.
Agreement: Makenga, leader of M23, and several hundred M23 fighters, surrendered to Uganda military at Mgahinga National Park.
Report refers to land problems between communities and police clashing with angry residents for land rights but is not specific.
Kampalas city mayor, an opponent of the President, was dismissed from office sparking protests. Protesters opposed the decision and pelted police with stones. Police fired teargas into the crowds.
Police stop, arrest, beat and torture a journalist for the Associated Press.
Security Measures: Uganda closes border with South Sudan and increases troop presence.

3 people ended up dead after a police man shot a man suspeted of stealing a phone. After police shot the man, two other men went after the officers. Police who shot the civilians are under investigation.

Clashes between South Sudanese refugees in Elegu camp in Amuru District and those in Nzaipi in Adjumani District. ""clashes in Elegu cropped up after three men from the Nuer tribe stabbed a man who is believed to be from the Dinka tribe with a knife after a bitter exchange."" Police say incidents occur daily.
Community mob in Asinge killed a man who was suspected to have robbed and raped his neighbor.
The Kibiniko militia attacked foreigners surveying the wetlands.
A letter bomb was sent to Parliament Speaker Rebecca Kadaga. Her aide opened the letter bomb and was hospitalised.
Police sexually and physically assaulted a transgender man, also paraded him before the media
Unidentified armed group fought with police. 1 police officer died and 2 of the armed group died. The shooting took place in Kampala in Nalumunye near the Jomayi Estates .
Unidentified armed group shot and killed a police officer in Kampala in Kajjansi town .
A man was killed in ""Kiwogozi zone in Luweero and was reportedly behind a group called B-13, known for terrorising residents at night. ""
On 17 February 2014, two people were shot in Luwero, it is suspected the gunmen were after a witch doctor.

Since the passing of the Anti-Pornography Act, women have been stripped in the streets and incidents of sexual violence increased; police have forced women to uncloth in pubic if wearing a inappropriate clothing. ""These women and girls who are citizens of Uganda have been stripped naked by gangs of men on the pretext that they are indecently dressed. ""
Students at Kyambogo University blocked the Chancellor fromentering the campus. Police fired teargas at the students.
Three university were raped then killed in the month of February after the passing of the Anti-Pornography Act
After a tabloid released the names of 200 homosexual individuals, one person on the list was killed.
Security measures: Police instituted a curfew in response to killings in Lowero the month of February.

An Anti-Gay Bill and Anti-Pornagraphy Act has encouraged attacks against women and banned mini-skirts. In response, women protesters demonstrated against the Act and attacks. Riot police tried to stop the march.

column8: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Presidential Security Unit
column17: A member of the Presidential Guard grabbed a soldiers gun and shot him several times. Other soldiers of the Presidential Guard responded by shooting the initial shooter. Both men died.
A group of three men were attacked for being homosexual. All were admitted to the hospital.
A woman was """"paraded"" before local media, outed as a transsexual, beaten, undressed and arrested"" by police forces.
Tensions between South Sudan refugees and host community have escalated. An assault on one refugee took place over scarce resources.
Police and Military fired teargas and bullets to disperse rioters/crowds that gathered after a group of opposition leaders were blocked from holding a rally.

column6: Military Forces of the United States (2009-2017)
column17: Movement of forces: US sent troops to Uganda to assist with capturing Kony.
