Unknown gunmen assassinated on Wednesday 6th South Sudanese MP Jacob Kuwinsuk Gale in the district of Yumbe. The MP was in the company of other people making consultations as part of the national dialogue for South Sudanese refugees in Uganda. No armed group has claimed the attack so far.

On December 7th, around 40 people took part in a peaceful protest organised by the Pan-African Pyramid, a non-partisan organization who ideal is to revive 'intellectual' discourse on Pan-Africanism. The protesters demonstrated in front of the Lybian embassy against the reports of slave trade in the country, demanding to know whether the reports were true or false, and asking for the government to formally recognise the United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) and allow it fully carry out its mandate.

During a march from Ugandan Democratic Party members in Kampala, on the way to the Parliament, on December 12th, police arrested the party president general - Norbert Mao - and 11 other party members. The group was marching to Parliament to protest against the proposed scrapping of the presidential age limit. The 12 are being held on tentative charges of holding an unlawful procession.

column8: Military Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: President Museveni allows for a joint military cooperation between Uganda and DRC to fight the insurgent ADF forces.

Non-violent activity: 50 soldiers/presidential police members entered Uganda's Parliament on Monday 18th December when the age limit bill that would allow President Museveni's presidency to continue was being discussed. Several reports mention that soldiers took over the Catholic and Anglican chaplains. The soldiers' presence sparked fears over the security of the MPs, which in turn led to a scuffle on Tuesday morning when the house resumed debating the contentious age limit amendment bill, resulting in the debate being adjourned and restarted two hours later.

A Rwandan refugee was surrounded by RNC members and Mukombozi members in a shopping mall in Ntinda, Kampala, on the week of the 24th of December. He was taken to Katuna border, where he was brought to Kigali and allegedly blindfolded and beaten.
Shots were heard during the day in Busunga because of clashes between the UPDF and ADF, on December 24th.
On December 25th, a group of residents of Odek sub county exercised mob justice on another resident who had stolen a bull. The victim was beaten up and died in the hospital.

Raid: an unidentified group of 3 armed men attacked the Offices of the Citizens' Coalition for Electoral Democracy in Nsambya, Uganda, on December 26th, with a security guard having his gun taken before the raid. The raid was confirmed by the Office's coordinator, but the reports were rejected and delegitimised by the police.
A policeman was victim of mob justice on January 1st, in the Makindye Division, in Kampala. The motive for the killing is allegedly that the officer was involved in a motorcycle robbery.

On January 2nd, an unidentified group of armed people attacked the districts of Lwengo (village of Kiryasaaka) and Bukomansimbi (villages of Kisojjo, Kyabagoma and Kyamabaale). 5 people were killed and 12 others were injured. 2 fatalities recorded in Lwengo.

On January 2nd, an unidentified group of armed people attacked the districts of Lwengo (village of Kiryasaaka) and Bukomansimbi (villages of Kisojjo, Kyabagoma and Kyamabaale). 5 people were killed and 12 others were injured. 3 fatalities recorded in Kibinge.

NRM Protesters took to the street in front of the Civil Division of the High Court in Kampala protesting litigations against Parliament Speaker Rebecca Kadaga. The group claims that Kadaga is being targeted over presiding the proceedings that led to the passing of the age limit law. The protesters argued that Kadaga had nothing to answer to in regards to the bill having passed, which they claim happened in the right manner.

After the Luwero town issued a notice for the relocation of Binyonyi farmers market from Luwero-Kiwoto to Kiyenje, traders did not comply. They set up their market on January 8th, and reportedly pelted the police with stones, In retaliation, the police dispersed them by resorting to tear gas. 3 traders were arrested for inciting violence.

On 14 January 2018, a Burundian refugee in Nakivale camp in Uganda was attacked by unidentified people. According to him, the sponsors of the attack are from Bujumbura. The perpetrators set his vehicle on fire and his house was hit by flames.

After arrests of several members of the Boda Boda 2010 militia by the military, and another arrest of one member on Friday 19 January, the members of the militia took to the streets of Kampala to protest. The police used tear gas and live bullets to disperse the crowd, but the members of the militia blocked streets and threatened with more violence if their member was not released.

On January 22nd, the Boda Boda militia raided the offices of the rival group Boda Boda 2010 in different parts of Kampala, where office material was set ablaze (locations include Wakaliga, Katwe, Makindye, Natete, Nsangi and Kyengera among others). The development followed the arrest the day prior of some members of the Boda Boda 2010 militia group, including its leader Abdallah Kitatta, who was held in connection to a murder case.
A UPDF officer killed 2 civilians in Arua, Ayivu district, on January 31st, before killing himself.

On February 5th, mob justice was exerted on a man who was trying to rob a bodaboda motorcycle. The same man is believed to have murdered a police officer last year in Mbarara. Residents of Keihangara Sub County in Ibanda district beat the man to death after he was found with an AK-47, despite having no rounds.
On February 7, in Kampala city (Kampala, Kampala), unidentified actors killed a woman who was an administrator of a prominent local farm for unknown reasons.

Property destruction: on February 9th, an unidentified group raided the offices of a local NGO at 3am, not stealing anything, but destroying the place. This attack comes in the sequence of a series of mysterious attacks aimed at civil society organisations.

Human Rights Awareness and Promotion Forum's premises were broken into on February 9th by 9 unidentified armed men who attacked 2 security guards after disabling the security system. The 2 individuals sustained severe injuries.

On February 12, the UDPF laid siege to the Guardian Primary school under the claim that the institution was illegally using their land. Upon being surrounded, the principal called for students and parents to forcefully enter the school. The ensuing situation led to some of the people being injured by the police.
A 13 year old boy died in Musoni village, Kamet Sub-county, on February 14th, due to the detonation of a grenade.

column16: Chimp Reports; Daily Monitor (Uganda); Weekly Observer
column17: On February 15, 2 police officers stationed in Kizza zone, Kawempe Division, were killed by unknown assailants and had their guns stolen.
On Friday February 16, a man was clobbered to death by a mob in Kihihi, due to being accused of stealing 2 chickens.

Police officers chased and whipped several journalists who were covering the trial of former Buyende DPC Muhammad Kirumira in Kololo, Kampala. Journalists who were covering the event were waiting for them at the location when they were assaulted by police, who beat and punched them, forcing them to flee. These reports of violence are denied by the police.

On February 23rd, the SPLA kidnapped 5 South Sudanese refugees and raided over 200 herds of cattle from Gbari and Arapi villages in Metu. The attack started with the intention to drive the cattle to South Sudan. By then, one of the abducted refugees had already allegedly been killed. 2 others managed to escape while the UPDF's chased the rebels 60km into South Sudan.
Arrests: after another round of kidnappings in Kampala, police arrested 27 suspects. 16 were charged under the court of law and 11 are under inquiry.

Students of Dr Obote College, in Boroboro, went on rampage destroying public property and the head teacher's premises allegedly after the school declined a proposal for a disco after the religious service. According to a student, they were protesting the continued stay of the head teacher Fred Kiwanuka. The event stopped when police used tear gas and bullets to disperse the students.

Unidentified armed men slit a woman's throat in Jinja road, in Bweyongerere, on March 1st. She was taken to the hospital for treatment. Police, who was located nearby, pursued the gunmen and killed two.

On March 2nd, Acholi and Paluo militia clashed at Bedmot village (coordinates for Mutanda sub-county, Kiryandongo, used). Four people were injured (though the source does not specify the identity of the victims), and at least 7 houses were torched. The event represents an escalation in a land dispute, connected to a former Paluo MP.
300 students of the Kabale Institute of Health Science marched in Kabale on March 5 protesting maladministration, mistreatment and poor services at the institute.

On the week of 5 March, youth protested at the Kingdom headquarters in Bugembe, promising not to allow Minister Namuganza to go to Bugosa unless she apologised for her comments on Kyabazinga Wilberforce Gabula Nadiope IV and Speaker Rebecca Kadaga.

Police had to intervene in a protest organised by Kyambogo University students on March 6th, when they protested the postponement of the voting for the student guilds. Police also arrested 2 guild members and an unspecified number of other students.
On March 9, a UPDF member was lynched in public in Kamwezi Sub County.

During March and April 2018, soldiers evicted over 6,000 villagers from their lands in Pakwach district. The soldiers burned down huts, beat the villagers severely, and stole livestock and property. This land has now been occupied by a senior UPDF official. Coded as two events per month with a date precision of 2.
On 11 March, a UPDF soldier was killed - Pte Ibrahim Congo - by South Sudanese gunmen in Padiga (Metu), during an operation to recover 836 animals.

On 11 March, rival supporters clashed in Nakabango during the Land Minister Namuganza's visit of Prince Edward Columbus Wambuzi's palace. The pro-Kyabazinga Nadiope/Kadaga supporters wanted to lynch the Minister but were confronted by the pro-Namuganza. Some injuries and arrests reported.

Arrests: on 13 March, 40 supporters of the FDC were arrested in Jinja by police, ahead of the Jinja East Constituency by-election scheduled for the next day and while they held a post-campaign evaluation meeting for the FDC candidate, Mr Paul Mwiru. Another report mentions 48 arrests.

On 15 March, boda boda riders blocked the Kampala-Gulu highway while protesting against the violence used by police members against several riders. The protest was a direct reaction to the police's intervention the day before, impouding dozens of uninsured motorcycles belonging to boda boda riders. The protest took hours, with rioters pelting stones and police using tear gas and live bullets shot in the air.
On 16 March, a group of tax collectors ambushed the Local Council 5 Chairman of Isingiro near Mile 4, along Isingiro. They beat him and damaged his car.

Property destruction: On 16 March, soldiers began an eviction exercise in Apaa. They burned down huts and forced residents to leave. The Ugandan Wildlife Authority has decreed that the 15,000 residents in Apaa must vacate their property.
On 17 March, a group of over 70 people wielding pangas attached the Ishaka-Basajjabalaba Mosque protested in Bushenyi. The police arrested 3 protesters.
On 17 March 2018, the Local Council 5 Chairman of Isingiro organised a militia to launch a counter-attack on a group of tax collectors who had beaten him the previous day.

On 18 March, a group of Muslim men wielding pangas attached the Ishaka-Basajjabalaba Mosque protested in Bushenyi. They were repelled by the police, with support from the army. This group is unhappy with the leadership of the district Kadhi.
On March 20, in Kampala city (Kampala, Kampala), Inspector General of Police (IGP) Ochola reorganized the command and supervision of all 13 specialized units in the police force.

During March and April 2018, soldiers evicted over 6,000 villagers from their lands in Pakwach district. The soldiers burned down huts, beat the villagers severely, and stole livestock and property. This land has now been occupied by a senior UPDF official. Coded as two events per month with a date precision of 2.
During the week of 21 March, residents of Kyelinda village, in Buwenge, stoned 2 men to death. The men were accused of stealing goats.

During the week of 21 March, a group of unidentified men wielding spears and pangas, supported by the police, attacked the residents of Ceke village, in Nwoya. The militia were deployed by a local businessman who is in a land dispute with the villagers. A villager was stabbed in the back, a child ran away, 11 huts were burned, 20 granaries were destroyed, and shops and supplies were looted.

During the week of 18 March, UPDF soldiers came to the house of a man living on a farm in Obira Parish, Got Apwoyo, in Nwoya. They ordered him out of his hut, set the hut on fire, and then beat him until he passed out. The land is wanted by a senior general.
On 23 March, soldiers carrying out a forceful eviction of residents in Apaa shot at the residents. One person died and two were seriously injured.
On 26 March, students at Kabale University marched to the office of the Resident District Commissioner to protest the expensive fees.
On 26 March, there was a peaceful demonstration at the Nakawa Chief Magistrates Court to protest the release of a professor accused of pouring acid on his lover.
On 27 March, subjects of the Busoga Kingdom staged a peaceful demonstration in Kamuli against the State Minister for Lands, whom they accuse of disrespecting the Busoga king.

column9: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-); Military Forces of Uganda (1986-)
column17: On 27 March, Uganda Revenue Authority officials were attacked by a crowd of Boda Boda drivers when they tried to enforce registration in Yumbe. Their private security forces fired into the air. The crowds then attacked and destroyed cars and property. The police and military had to be brought in to calm the town.
During the week of 28 March, residents of Kyotera tried to lynch a man accused of raping a young girl. They stormed his house and attacked him with clubs. The police intervened and arrested the man.
On 4 April, suspected SPLA soldiers who had crossed into Uganda clashed with UPDF and the Uganda Police Force in Dufile. The Ugandan forces defeated the SPLA. There were no reported casualties.
On 4 April, suspected SPLA soldiers who had crossed into Uganda clashed with UPDF and the Uganda Police Force in Metu. The Ugandan forces defeated the SPLA. There were no reported casualties.
On 5 April, police and rioters engaged in running battles near a refugee camp in Arua. The police arrested an LCIII Chairman and 6 other Ugandans and accused them of inciting riots against refugees.
On 5 April, residents in Mityana rioted to protest against the poor state of roads. They barricaded the roads and burned car tyres. The police intervened to contain the rioters.
On April 6th, a lynch mob killed a man in Kibungo (Rubanda district, coordinates for Kaara used at precision 2), on suspicion that he had killed his father earlier that day. [size=no report]

column8: Mutiny of Military Forces of Uganda (1986-)
column17: On April 6th, a UPDF deserter attacked a man using hand weapons in Nyagicyebe village (coordinates for Rwaramba parish, Kisoro district, used at precision 2). A mob formed and killed the soldier. The motive for the attack is unclear. [size=small]

On April 7th, a police officer attempted to prevent a student from being attacked by a rival student football team in Mutolere (Kisoro district), and shot one of the attackers in the leg. The officer was placed under arrest. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
column17: On April 7th, a man described as ""loitering"" in the vicinity of Moroto airstrip (Moroto district) was shot dead by a member of the LDU, who was guarding the airstrip.

During March and April 2018, soldiers evicted over 6,000 villagers from their lands in Pakwach district. The soldiers burned down huts, beat the villagers severely, and stole livestock and property. This land has now been occupied by a senior UPDF official. Coded as two events per month with a date precision of 2.
On 11 April, youth marched to the High Court in Mbale to protest the age limit bill. They were intercepted and prevented from marching by the police.
During the week of 11 April, residents of Mukoko village attacked and killed a man who was suspected of attacking and robbing people.

On April 15th, residents of Bugomora village protested at an unspecified location along the road linking Nyabubare (Bushenyi district, coordinates used) to Kizinda, to highlight the very poor condition of the road. The source notes that demonstrators blocked the road, but does not specify how (actor 1 coded as protesters), and that police intervened to end the protest. [size=no report]
On 16 April, protesting students clashed with the police at Makerere University. The police arrested 6 students.
On 17 April, residents on William Street in Kampala gathered to protest the broken sewage system, however the police prevented them from marching.
On 17 April, clashes between protesting students and police at Makerere University continued.
On 17 April, MP Paul Mwiru and his supporters demonstrated outside the Kira police station to protest against the arrest of opposition supporters. The police dispersed the protesters.

On April 19th, a lynch mob killed two men in Awielem village in Adekokwok subcounty (Lira district, coordinates for Boroboro used at precision 2), on the suspicion that they had stolen a goat. [size=small]

During March and April 2018, soldiers evicted over 6,000 villagers from their lands in Pakwach district. The soldiers burned down huts, beat the villagers severely, and stole livestock and property. This land has now been occupied by a senior UPDF official. Coded as two events per month with a date precision of 2.

On April 21st, a lynch mob killed a man at an unspecified location in Abim subcounty (Abim district, coordinates for Abim used at precision 2) as he travelled to Kanu village in the subcounty. The man was accused of stealing two goats. [size=small]

On April 22nd, a police officer shot an 18 year-old man (the source implies the victim was shot in the genitals), with the victim dying of his wounds on the following day. The event occurred in Kikajjo zone (Wakiso). There is no established motive for the attack, and the officer has been charged with murder.

On April 23nd, residents from six villages in Bwijanga subcounty blocked the Kigumba-Bulima road at an unspecified location (coordinates for Bwijanga town, Masindi district, used at precision 2), to highlight the poor quality of the road. Residents used logs, and dug a hole in the road. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Uganda Wildlife Authority
column17: On 23rd April, park rangers in the Mgahinga National Park (Kisoro district) shot a man dead. They claim that they believed he was a poacher, however, local residents claimed that the man was gathering firewood and was clearly disabled, so could not have been confused with a poacher.

column6: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Presidential Security Unit
column17: On 23 April, soldiers in the First Lady's guard beat a university professor at Makerere University.

On April 24th, a police officer shot and wounded two civilians in Kikumikikumi zone (coordinates for Wandegeya, Kampala, used). The victims were the girlfriend of the police officer, and a man who he suspected of being romantically involved with his girlfriend. Both were shot in the legs. The officer has been arrested for attempted murder.
On 25 April, demonstrators protested against poor service delivery and president Museveni in Kashambya
On 25 April, demonstrators protested against poor service delivery and president Museveni in Kamwezi
On 25 April, demonstrators protested against poor service delivery and president Museveni in Muhanga

On 25th April, residents of Nyagakenke village marched to the Kisoro District offices and protested. They demanded the release of the body of a man shot by Mgahinga National Park rangers on April 23rd. Following the protest, four suspects were arrested. [size=200]
On 25 April, demonstrators protested against poor service delivery and president Museveni in Rwamucucu
On 26 April, rioters burned down materials at the Kisekka market. Police was shown as present in the area but it is unclear if they engaged the rioters.
